V-rs7jGVoV2HfrD46ICWHw.text: I had so much fun here last night. It's not somewhere you go randomly, we had to book in advance and you can only stay for 45 minutes which makes it seem like such a money maker but i still had fun. You get given cool capes and gloves when you arrive and the £15 cover charge includes one free drink out of a glass that is made of ice, its a square though so surprisingly hard to drink out of. Also the drinks are really small and obviously made with absolute vodka but tasty nonetheless. One problem is the lack of seating, but I suppose everyone would be freezing to blocks of ice if they were everywhere. And they'd melt too fast. Its really dark inside and the music is very atmospheric, its such a novel place to visit. The kind of place I'd go once though, been there done that. Had a laugh.

68OMxsOp6ha_OYtWhPeU_g.text: Mental - this place is awesome and totally unique. There are two halves to it, the top bar and the icebar: the top half of the bar is pretty cool, great tunes, really good nibbles and some great and unusual drinks (some v. expensive whiskeys!) but the icebar is what you go there for. ITs all made of ice, and you hang out basically ina big fridge for half an hour, drinking out of ice cups, sitting on beautiful carved ice chairs, and ordering from an ice bar, its nuts.

lp1PXKhqUwghedNGjbFTRw.text: I think the Absolut Ice Bar is quite a disappointment personally. There was so much hype about this place when I went that I was having too much expectation of it. Basically, it a tiny room made of ice with a bar counter made of ice serving drinks out of 'ice glasses' at a rip-off price. I was in there less than 10mins and I was beginning to get bored. I left earlier that the time slot allocated for me. In conclusion, it's an overrated place that I will not be returning for sure.

mkfhQdl9XChce3FF9mYNDg.text: I think the Absolut Ice bar is a great experance but 20 mins in the cold and the cocktail is not that nice they give you is a little disapointing. I wish there was more of the choice on drinks.

zvJ4TrW0f5S2CGzLcrS5SA.text: I wasn't sure how to rate this - on one hand it deserves the thumbs up for being different, you dont get the chance to sip cocktails in ice glasses in an ice buiding very often, but i was a tad dissapointed with my experience. I thought that 45 minutes would not be long enough, but the trouble is, once you have gone in ,done the whole -ooohhh - stuff,and picked out your 'free' drink you're just left standing around going - is this it? Can i go now? I think it is over priced. I reckon it is a bit of a con, because you dont get much to drink - your free drink is tiny. After ten mins you end up buying another one because there is not much else to do. All in all, yes give it a go once. You may or may not enjoy, but you probabaly wont want to come back.

JUJd4_kpe-Sir2WcA1BhHg.text: This is definiteley not a place to visit regularly with a group of mates on a Friday night but it is well worth the experience. If you can picture everything made from ice, even the glasses you drink from then you're somewhere there. It is unbelievable, who ever thought of the concept is a genious, a rather loaded genious with a large water bill mind. I think punters just forget to talk and stare round in amazement and the only speech you here now and again is "oh! look they made that out of ice too!" erm... the place is truly marvellous but more a mueseum than a drinking venue.

QOxdfOZegrJUe-lURTXzJg.text: What a fantastic place to go for something different! The entire bar area is made from ice, including the glasses!! You have to put on special coats and gloves etc over your own clothes and your only allowed in for about 40 minutes but what an enjoyable 40 minutes it is!! The cocktails are lovely - you get one included in the entrance price and then you can pay extra for a top up if you like. Highly recommended if you have friends visiting London or just want to do something different.

wfAx8rUC1gKM1jPuBQ9EtA.text: I was very dissapointed by the ice bar. In my opinion it is overpriced and the choice of vodka cocktails is too limited. Having said that it is a very different night out and when I took my friend who was over from the states he loved it.

JvIGp9Hit9NXaQxeC67Ywg.text: An excellent place for a couple or a group, the ice is an art form all of its own. The bubbles and changes of ice structure were wonderful. The cocktails are also great and you will centainly remember it as a highlight of your visit to London.

MASrh2hz8KVufJOiHGk8pg.text: Great ! Off my checklist of things to do in London !!!Cocktails are quite prICEy, though quite original in names and composition.You have to queue for a bit to get in, as they can only allow so many people in there, as it's quite small, and for 30 minutes only.It was very nICE in the end, and since it's not humid nor windy, the cold is not bothering at all...I would think twICE about going there again, when new friends or family are in town, so see you there !!!!

hZ7ysCIz9bTf1uu0OX0HHA.text: The Ice Bar was ice cold but not overdone, and the layout is good, with two tables, a bar and a kissing igloo. Drinks were creative mixes that were hit or miss (some tasted a little weird, but a few were very good! Like the voyager, order it when you're there trust me ;)Definitely worth going to if your around Piccadilly. It's a fun experience, and better than the Ice Bar I went to in Las Vegas. Not too expensive as far as ice bars go. The ground floor is well put together, nice decor, comfy seats, though the bar there is more pricey than the Ice bar itself. We scheduled to go to the icebar at 715 on a wednesday, arrived 10 mins before, and had a great time, no problem with the queue.Only complaint I had was that the coat they gave me smelled a little funky, they could wash that.. because of that, they get 4 stars, not 5

Ij6J9iAOkj96M_Ohjmoiyw.text: Fun!Came here with a few friends while on holiday in London. We'd heard about it from a friend who had been to London before and decided to give it a go.Once you get there, you pay a cashier an entrance fee (which includes one drink) and they fit you with a blue cloak with a fuzzy fur lined hood to keep you warm inside the bar which is completely made of ice.Apparently they change the interior a few times a year so you won't experience the same exact thing each time you go (if you plan on going more than once). It's not something I personally would do more than once (unless I got an open bar deal, which they have sometimes). We each tried a different drink so that we could taste each others'. They were fresh and delicious and were served in cups made of ice. The bartender was also outfitted in some cutesy winter wear.There were a few tables and seats made of ice but they were all occupied so we ended up having to dawdle around the standing area. Be careful with your cups! Since they're made of ice and sitting on another ice surface, there isn't much friction which means you might lose your drink.It was definitely a fun experience, v. touristy, and entertaining. I would recommend it.

kDVaRmFucqpt73xbWcc0pw.text: A friend and I decided to go after class; since our lecture ends at 5pm, we had to hurry and jump on the Tube and and get there before 5:45, the last session of the day that was 13.50 pounds. Why pay more when you can go for the lowest price?We were the first ones to arrive for the 5:45pm session, so we were the first ones inside the bar. A woman helped us get a parka on and we headed in. It was nice being the first ones in since we could snap pictures before it got crowded. The theme was deep sea =) I was dazzled by the intricate design of the ice. By the time we decided to get our drinks, everyone had trickled in. It took us about 15 minutes to get our drinks with people jumping in when people left the bar rather than wait their turn. There were only 2 bartenders, but they were pretty efficient; I watched a bartender make 4 drinks at once.My friend and I each ordered the Absolut Deep Blue (Absolut Peach, Blue Curacao, Watermelon juice); it was really good! I've taken shots of Absolut vodka before and it's rather gross. The combination of ingredients in the Deep Blue made for an enjoyable drink.You're allowed to stay 45 minutes, but after half an hour we were cold and left after we finished our drinks. The parkas keep you warm enough, but the gloves dont. Your glass is made of ice, so you can see how this is a problem...Also, for those of you going for the first time: wear closed-toed shoes and pants!They do have non-alcoholic drinks on the menu, so children are allowed in. I was confused at first when I saw a child, but then I remembered there were juice drinks on the menu. They also have a photographer that goes around taking your picture. You can buy the photo for 10 pounds...

tsiEl2cZ5b-XAZWLvm5b1Q.text: Oh, so cool...I immediately organised an outing for my group.The booking process was easy peasy, lemon squeezy. Got there & queued up (very short), got our cloaks and gloves and headed inside the Ice Bar.You get a complimentary drink with the purchase of your stay in the Ice Bar, so I had the Absolut Ice Bar (formerly named) drink. Everything is made of ice including your glass. Don't go in there asking for anything other than vodka 'cause they don't have it. Although, since the name change this may be different now.The drink was as strong & it needed to be. We walked (stomped our cold feet) around looking at the ice sculptures and sipping our cocktails. You can take pics in here but I recommend you keep moving initially until you acclimate to the cold. You only get about 40 minutes in here, which is plenty of freezing time.Many people started to abandon the ship as they clearly were not keen on being cold for so long. I'm used to NYC winters so I could tough it out.

z5uacxoe6Rjwtf28Dn6R6Q.text: The Ice Bar doesn't interest me in the least bit, but the restaurant attached to it did actually impress me (more so than I predicted, anyway). Although a sad event as we were saying goodbye to a dear friend as she prepared to make her way back to the States, the food and drinks provided a a great vibe as we all shared each others' dishes and tasted the delightful drinks.The plates are small, but there are so many combinations you can create for a relatively good price. If you request it from the servers, some of them will allow you to mix and match throughout the combos. The price is a little steep for the serving size, but it's a great place to come and try out a couple of great dishes without ending up entirely unable to walk. The drinks are tasty as well. The Chocolatini was a favorite among the table. It was warm, sweet, and had the perfect kick. You could smell the marshmallow, and the way they present the drink is by itself cool.

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. "House hot-smoked salmon, potato rosti, spinach, horseradish hollandaise"

Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Crispy chorizo, stewed apples, blue cheese & salt 'n pepper prawns, chilli, garlic

McHKKywQsYsx6PMffaMRZw.text: The Icebar is a place youcould easily walk past without noticing which is great as behind those doors isa great cocktail bar, untouched by the masses. Having said that I wouldrecommend that you book ahead and reserve a table to avoid disappointment!Thecocktails are expensive the drinks are not strong but you have your choice ofvodka, whiskey and tequila in addition to uncharged champagne. Reallyworthit is since the drinks are OK. Atleast they're not watered down with melted ice.

Ikppl8m-zYcw3y97HgVq2Q.text: I was lucky enough to attend their galactic launch party, and i was impressed, i havent been before so was not entirely sure what to expect. After a few tequilla cocktails we were taken into the waiting area where we sampled a tequilla sorbet and a tequilla toothpaste concoction - very bizarre but lethal alcohol zing lol.I loved the outfits of the staff and the dj.We were given capes and gloves and sampled 2 coctails 1 blue 1 red and oh so nice. I even tried a sangrita ice lolly which was awful unfortunately someone took my pic showing my expression lol.I really enjoyed the novelty of this experience and look forward to going back and trying out one of their meal deals

xtEOFU4xPVMVgciuZowPJA.text: What do you need in the middle of a swelteringly hot day in August, cooling down! Well this is London so it wasn't exactly that hot, but enough to one a nice refreshing and cool drink. Where better to grab one than served in an ice cube in an ice bar!So to start, you have to book. When you book, you get charged £13 for 45 minutes in the bar and you think how outrageously expensive! But then you realise that you get a drink thrown in for that so you think, maybe it's not that bad as long as the drink is ok.We turned up early and ordered a cheeky bottle of wine to be getting along with. £20 for house white?! What a load of rubbish. So was the wine. Not happy.Then we went in and put on our ice fur-lined capes and mittens, which they insist you wear because YOU'RE GOING IN AN ICE BAR. I get that, but you think it can't be that bad, right? Wrong! It's freezing in there!! Of course that's expected I suppose. Also a good thing, otherwise it would be a water bar. Of course I say bar, and there is a bar in there. Also some chairs, tables and cool corner with a photo opportunity wall (of course we took full advantage). But it's quite small and not that impressive. I wish I could say WOW LOOK AT THE ICE SCULPTURES IT'S JUST LIKE FROZEN. No, it wasn't. But it was a gimmick and for that I was happy. The drink was also rather scrummy, if you wanted more drinks it cost £6 more. Probably about what the drink was worth, some pre-mixed cocktails thing you could buy in any upmarket Wetherspoons. I can see why it was only 45 minutes as well. First it's FREEZING in there. I took my mittens off to take some photos and felt like frostbite has set in when I put them back on. Never has going out into lukewarm London been so appealing. Second, there's nothing to do in there. Give it 15/ 20 minutes of photo opps and having your drink and you're done. We stretched it out another 10 minutes because we had a race to see who could lick through their ice cube glass first (thanks so much, I won that one!)So yeah, go along. But don't expect the ice palace. And don't go twice

MI63EbyX1L5QtGNtbSiAwQ.text: This bar is never going to be your "Local", but to be honest, that's not what it's all about! It is a London MUST for any trip...A chance to pretend I'm in the Rebel Base on Hoth, how could i pass this up :DOn arrival, you get introduced to a nice staging area complete with a cocktail bar, whilst you wait for your session, though I do think that there are much cheaper places to drink before hand! Once it's your turn in the actual ICEBAR you all get your own "Thermal Poncho", leaving you looking like a character from the old Arcade game Ice Climber. That said, i strongly recommend you wrap up warm before hand, as you're still spending 45 minutes at -7...Once inside, you get your first cocktail for free but have options to buy more, but to be honest, the cocktails themselves are incidental as well as overpriced.Much more fun is trying to put your glass made of ice down on a bar made of ice without it skating away out of reach! The time limit may seem short but it's just long enough to enjoy your drink, pose next to ice sculpture and generally act like a 6 year old on a snow day, but short enough that the novelty doesn't wear off!Overall, well worth the price, and does make for an interesting night out!

hFivSbs8CVEKwATQg1e0wQ.text: I came to the ICEBAR when I studied abroad in London back in 09 and I'm a huge fan.  It was one of the really exciting things I remembered about London.  A group of us decided to hit it up one night because we heard so much about it.  It's truly a unique place.  Slightly expensive but not enough to stop us curious college Americans.  You have a certain time limit when you go in there, which is alright I suppose.  We were able to be in there for about 37 minutes and after that, they tell you to go back upstairs because they can't have guests staying pass the time due to how cold it is.  However, for us it wasn't cold at all.  They give you these really awesome thermal hooded cloaks with gloves attaches to them!  Along with this, you get to choose whichever drink you'd like and it comes in a block of ice.  While you're down in the freezer part of the bar, there are some really amazing ice figures.  The bartenders were really cool too. Once we were back upstairs, we stayed for a little while longer at the warm part of the bar.  However, I didn't order a drink because of their ungodly prices.  I think one mixed drink was 12 pounds (about 24 US dollars).  Too much for a lowly college student.  Prices aside though, it was definitely a great place to hang out if you haven't experienced it before.  I believe there's only one in the U.S. so if you're anywhere else that has an Ice Bar in your area, try to hit it up!  Some are quite different than others but they're all pretty neat to experience.

HpkxgaoT95aljCJL_7Fl2Q.text: Is ICEBAR touristy?  Yes.  Is it gimmicky?  Absolutely.  Are the drinks a little on the weak side?  Yeah, I'd say so.  Did we have fun?  We did!We also had a few drinks in the lounge before going in to the ice room (as I like to think of it) and they were definitely not watered down.  In fact, I was pretty impressed with the cocktail list in the non-ice bar section of the room.  I probably wouldn't go back unless I had friends in town, but it's a fun thing to experience once.

Xx2geQpFUAhj4yDchcYeRw.text: Such a fun activity to do in London! Never done anything like it before and I recommend trying it out. Be aware that the drinks are somewhat expensive and strong, but if are you looking for something novel to do in London, check this place out.The only downfall is that our waitress in the lounge was a little rude and the drinks are overpriced.

slUZm7SwPlKjFt6KpU3zIA.text: The novelty of being in a bar made of ice is quite fun! For 15 £, you get entrance and a free drink coupon. They'll provide you a furry coat/cape and gloves to wear. The entire rooms is made of ice- walls, floors, bar table, etc. There are random things to take pictures with (ice phone booth, etc). You get an ice glass to drink out of. Their drink selection to choose from is small and very colorful. They highly discourage it, but patrons do drop/smash their ice glass on the floor (it is only ice). They've got colored lights and hit music playing.After we left the ice room, we continued the night in the regular bar area. The drinks are made tasty and strong. They were nice enough to replace a drink that got spilled.I had an awesome time here celebrating my birthday with friends. What topped the night was trying to figure out if that was really Jerry Springer (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Je…) at the other table. Why was he in London and why was he at Ice Bar? My friends started singing 'Happy Birthday' loudly and off key and inserted 'PAY ATTENTION JERRY SPRINGER' and it did sort of work. In the end, I went up to him when he got up and left his table and got a picture with him. Seriously, what an epic birthday and the night was still youngYeah it is pricey, but you should try it once. Its fun- live a little. You may even spot a celeb, who knows.Some picturesstatic.px.yelp.com/bphot…static.px.yelp.com/bphot…static.px.yelp.com/bphot…static.px.yelp.com/bphot…

idjbfOOK9htufFh63UGspw.text: Icebar is a really fun gimmicky tourist activity with good drinks served in all ice. The ponchos come with gloves so you can handle your ice drinks, so no worries there! Everything is really organized from the entry poncho line up to the drink system to the time countdown on the ice wall (each entry is 45 minutes). FYI the ground is not ice so you don't slip.

AedyIvVwclB7cOh3r16OFw.text: The first Ice Bar was at the Icehotel in northern Sweden, which was first built in 1989. Each year the Icehotel melts, and a new (bigger and better) one is constructed in the fall. Several years ago, the developer of the Icehotel had an idea of opening a permanent, year-round ice bar in Stockholm. Since then the famous bar has been franchised and you can even find one in Florida. I have been to the London and Stockholm Icebar, in general they are the same, i assume they are all similar. When in Sweden, at the Nordic Hotel the ice bar is attached to, i thought it was an interesting and unique concept. I hadnt realised it was a touristy franchise and thought i had stumbled upon a hidden gem. The bar is essentially a large walk-in freezer. Every surface except the floor is ice. The walls, the bar, the seats even the cups are cutouts of ice. The bar is most proud of the cups in fact, originally they were cut by hand from river ice blocks taken from the pristine, crystal-clear Torne River of northern Sweden. Soon the ice glasses were so popular that a factory and production line were set up to manufacture the frozen glasses. As it must be the bar is cold! As precaution, an unflattering poncho, a cross between an eskimo and star trek outfit, is provided. This garment is not truly intended to warm you however, its mostly intended to protect the ice from you. Further protection from our ice-melting body heat include gloves and sheepskins on seating surfaces. Ready to buy a drink? Hope you like absolut vodka because thats the only choice. Naturally anything else would freeze right? The concept is interesting, the experience is cool (pun intended) for about 15 minutes. As you walk about among all the other similar looking penguins you realise 4 things: 1. Its cold in here 2. Its expensive in here, do i really want another drink? 3. Everyone looks the same-silly. Where is the swedish ski team? 4. Its damn cold in here. Its an experience. Fits into the vegas mold of everyone should go at least once but no compelling reason to return. Makes for a good photo shoot and story. The fact that its been franchised and there is one in Orlando really cheapens the experience into just another touristy theme bar.

4fQSfVrs2dYnPltho0mSKQ.text: I only decided to go to the icebar because my friends were dying to go and were willing to pay for it. I mean, i agree that its amazing how basically the entire bar is made out of imported ice from sweden, but the drinks werent too fantastic and were over-priced. (cover is £15. drinks are around £6-£7...i think.) The experience, on the other hand, was interesting!! ....Or at least for the first 15 minutes. Other than that, the hype pretty much died. I do love how we got to wear cloaks/ponchos that were reminiscent of some high class space colony bar. And there's something intriguing about drinking out of ice glasses! At least i know that my drinks will never get watered down. The downsides: my giant of a friend could not fit the gloves and the poncho was too short for him. Im not sure if you have to specifically request a larger size, but they should have ponchos to fit all types of people. Also, the £15 cover only allows you 40 minutes...which honestly is way more than enough time to be in the bar. Other than that, i wouldnt go again unless i go with someone who hasnt been in one before. But i will admit that its one of those places that you have to try at least once in your life.

mBmoM3OYp3xuMivSjTg5zQ.text: Nothing better for a hang over than drinks in a Ice Bar. The afternoon after a brilliant birthday celebration, we went with our friends from Leeds and Manchester to the Ice Bar--their idea I might add--not the silly tourists' suggestion. It was novel and the drinks were strong--a chilly hair of the dog. It is in a great location so stop by and grab an ice block and rest your feet.

CubYvQKVWMCkUXk4QtaJwQ.text: So you have been to the Ice bar and experienced drinking and socialising at -5 degrees, well you probably need warming up then ? - If so pop next door into Below Zero and grab yourself a seat in one of the bars / lounges that are on offer over different levels of the building. You can eat here if you wish or just chill and listen to the live jazz or just chill in the main bar area. Whatever you decide you will be confronted by a quality feel and you will be made to feel welcome and well looked after. I like this place it really works but it may be a little to touristy for me - I guess that comes with the territory being right next door to the Ice bar. Alternatively it comes with being a grumpy old man ? - give it a go and see what you think, certainly worth a visit and combine it with Ice bar.

eT2HHls4NqE8kBMiiAF_FQ.text: The Ice Bar is a must try for the novelty value, but not the kind of place I'd go rushing back to. I'm not really sure what I expected, but it's actually quite small. They give you hooded thermal capes with gloves attached to wear but even so after about half an hour I was starting to feel rather cold  45 minutes is definitely long enough to be in there! The drinks are quite small, and the cocktails are premixed and not up to much, the mojito was the worst I've ever tasted, but you're there for the experience not the drinks.

N9RrCmvB4Kr_zubV5Txz4A.text: So - its basically high concept. It is what you'd imagine.Bar - You walk in and they take you up (expect people with lists) and then outside the bar area they throw a poncho coat over your head (they do throw it). and then you are in the bar.1 .It is quite cold2. It's for some reason quite blue. Then you hop over to the bar and get a cocktail (limited and uninteresting selection) and drink out of your glass. There are interesting sculptures the walls are covered with ice/ or are a wall of ice. It's a small room - everyone is doing the same - you go in, you have your drink then very quickly you are far too cold and scoot off. Cold/blue/small  it is what it is  - I'm glad I went - wouldn't again.-----RestaurantThis was quite good - the food was quite delightful, however the waiters have no idea, and the food wasn't cooked to order. here are the mild frustrations.1. 3 steaks ordered one medium/2 medium rare - they didn't really come cooked to order.2. The steaks that we paid £18 in advance for - had no substantial sides (chips or veg?!) we had to pay on top3. Either the waiter didn't know what the duck egg was (he said it was runny) or the chef screwed up - but i Basically paid £8 for a hard boiled egg...4. 12.5% service charge gets split between company and all staff - just take it off and give a cash tip to the waiting staff. Great food/stingy portions/Not cooked to order/Staff are illinformed, but really friendly.

_B7GtMLFmWveXAFTV7FTtQ.text: This was amazing, I've never been to an ice bar before. First drinks is free which is nice. Three stars because it's pricey and we weren't in there that long (maybe a half hour?) I live in New York and the ice bars in NYC have no time limit for similar prices.

VK2M71glw3PpvJgvC3U1ZQ.text: Not sure what's up with all the bad reviews of this place. Yes, it is very cheesy and definitely a one-off sort of spot. Keeping that in mind, I really like my visit to Icebar.I attended a Christmas party of sorts for a company that I don't even work for (long story). They were having cocktails in the lobby area, and booked a 45-minute stay in the Icebar. When the time arrived for us to enter, we were handed giant fluffy parkas complete with attached mittens.The actual Icebar itself is pretty small and absolutely everything is made of ice. It is quite cold inside (no surprise), and the chilly weather didn't exactly work well with my skirt and high heels. If I ever go again, I'll make it a point to wear warmer shoes.The bar was manned by two bartenders and we were given a cocktail menu that offered a decent selection of mainly vodka-based drinks. They're all served in, of course, ice cups. I tried 3 different cocktails - I can't remember their names - and they were all quite good. Vodka at such a cold temperature hardly has a taste, so everything tasted like fruit smoothies . . . except these smoothies got you drunk!The bartenders were quick, courteous, and I have no complaints. It is very touristy though, and I won't be back unless I happen to get invited to another party there. If you're curious about it and have been wanting to check it out, I recommend giving it a go. One visit won't hurt.

dWs5lvQ237utyHeFai0XRw.text: I came here about a week ago. I was excited to come because people were telling me about it and said I should visit there before I leave England.  First off let me say that the customer service and staff (on the top floor, including security) are so friendly. They were smiling, cracking jokes & very helpful. I would come back just for that alone. I just thought that I would mention that the cloak check is free. The actual IceBar is nice, and it's great for the first 20 mins. But after that it gets boring mainly due to the small room that it is in, make sure you go there with people who can hold good conversation. We got there On a Thursday evening so there wasn't really a wait list, if you make a reservation it is cheaper so consider that and do it days in advance. They place decent music I guess, I wish they added a bit of Top40 ( it would help people get through the 40 minute session). It was cold in there obviously, but it wasn't too bad. The coats they give you are not that thick, so bring your coat. Overall, the actual IceBar was nice, I would only go back in there if I was with people who have never been, so for that I give them 3 stars. The extra star is for the friendly staff, you can have conversations with them & they seem to really enjoy talking to you ( I love people like that).

Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Cocktail menu

JbyIkfsS5yAyTIfF20JGPA.text: If you're a tourist like me, or even if you aren't but haven't been to Ice Bar, you need to do the 40 minute ICEBAR Experience once.The 40 minute experience includes blue furry capes (even with a hood!), gloves, one complimentary cocktail, and entrance to a bar that's almost completely made of ice. The ambiance was great, it was cold, and the bartender was very helpful. 40 minutes may not seem like a lot, but you really do get the most out of it.Seats, sculptures, the counters, walls, and even your cocktail class is made of Swedish imported ice.I would recommend booking online, as they are cheaper when you preorder in advance. Sunday- Wednesday prices are the cheapest (12.50). Also, don't be late as they start kicking you out 40 minutes after your reserved time!Don't forget to bring your camera!

4wVg47VD79vcbkYuHFdFGA.text: What a funny experience to have in London ! We were more than 10 friends to go there and it was so much fun ! Sure, it's quite expensive (but we only paid 13£ for a weekday) but it's a one time thing !There is a really large choice of cocktails and it's really fun (and tricky) to drink them as you take pictures (be careful with your gloves)It's especially fun to try it during winter : when you get out in the street, it almost feels as if it's warm :)

7eiyV7MuaVBzTslNt03SBA.text: I was here during the summer. It was part of a week long visit to London. The day before I left, I decided to check this place out. It was pretty chill (no pun intended). It was tough to get around though. People were just standing around checking out the sculptures if they weren't at the bar getting drinks in the ice glasses. No, seriously, the glasses are made of ice.The people I met here while inside are like those I would meet at a regular club. But its mostly toward tourists (like me) and it was fun. Being from Hawaii it was my first time drinking in a place like this (outside of going to a midwest bar in 20 degree weather). I'd go again but only to get out of the summer heat.

Bm9-qP2tKqHUGx7-jN-p-g.text: Don't get me wrong, this place is GREAT. Basically you get 40 minutes wrapped in a fur jacket in a room covered with ice, it's random as hell. What's not to like? Iiiiiiif, you're not delayed. See, I was. I knew i'd be about 15minutes late (I got lost - not proud of it, but I did), so I gave them a call. The response I got was 'well, if you come up 15 minutes late you'll get 20 minutes in there'. Which was fair enough, I cocked up.I managed to get there only 10 minutes late (well recovered I feel) expecting to be quickly whisked into the room to make the most of my remaining 30 minutes.Yeah, that didn't happen. I walked into the empty reception which was manned by two guys, who blanked me and my girlfriend entirely and just had a nice chat. I interrupted them, only to be tutted at and pushed down the hall to the fur coat guys (the reception was pointless).The fur coat guys were fine, once we interrupted their conversation too, we were pushed into a small cold room which let us into the bar itself. When we got in, there was an ok amount of room - you kind of felt like sardines, but it wasn't too much of issue.You got your first drink 'free' - I say free, you already paid for it weeks ago when you book the tickets. So, now your feet are frozen to the floor (literally it felt sticky but your feet were frozen). You have one of there huge range (about 6) cocktails in your (pretty cool) ice glass.This is what you've come for - you're inside THE Ice Bar, and it is really impressive. Multi coloured lighting reflected through ice, TVs behind walls and seats made from a single block.So, the clock on the wall is ominously counting down to 00:00 and you've drank your drink (read half a drink - the cups are TINY) so you want another one. You go to the bar - the service HAS to be fast, you're on a timer after all. NOPE, I waited 5 minutes to be served - there was only one barman in the whole place.Normally, waiting at a bar is pretty standard - 5 minutes is normally pretty reasonable. Not when you're on a timer. I don't really have time to stare at the back of a barman's head when I'm being thrown out in t-minus 15 minutes 43 seconds. Writing this I feel a bit harsh but at the end of the day I paid to go to a bar to experience the amazing ice-covered epic. And at a MINIMUM of £13 per head (if you don't buy a £6.50 drink refill) with about 30 people every 45minutes, you can afford to hire a second barman.Eventually I got served, they don't take card in there so you have to start a tab and pay outside (finally the reception has a use!). The rest of the time was spent talking until at 3-minutes to go, we began to be herded out of the bar itself. They stopped the music and put up the lights. UNIMPRESSED.Overall, this is a cool place to go. It's a nice place to take your girlfriend/boyfriend. BUT it's somewhere you'd only go once. It's a gimmick at the end of the day, after all you can't have a night out in 40 minutes.

bbGJ5i9QliwwW9HU1bX4WQ.text: [NOTE: this review is only regarding the bar and not the restaurant]Should you go to this bar? Meh. Should you go to this bar once in a lifetime? well for 13£ why not,  but do not expect to come back again..The process of accessing to the bar, the person checking your reservations, and the ones giving you the poncho with gloves attached are really friendly and talky, and before entering in the actual bar the atmosphere seems classy but warm.And then you enter in the ice.And then you go into the ice. For real.The bar in sè it's nice, the idea of having everything built with ice is nice and everything else, but it's a bit small and without anything to look at... I mean, you build a bar entirely in ice, just put a damn sculpture, something! instead.. it's just a bar, a couple of tables and two benches. But the worst part, and the reason why the number of stars above is just 2, it's the actual bar service: the drink is included with the entrance, and we directly  went to the bar (well, not that you have many other things to do anyway!).At my question "Do you have anything bitter?" The answer simply was "No, you can choose among these" pointing at the chart. A chart with less than 10 cocktails. Yes I can read that chart man, the point is that I didn't find anything interesting, that's why I'm asking to you for anything bitter! But no, that's the chart and you can only choose from the chart. Damn. I don't consider it an actual bar service, I mean that's just rude and really, really sad for him.After 37 minutes... Lights go up, and music go down, after 40 a man comes in and tells you to go out.Yeah, great. Thanks Ice bar for the experience, I enjoyed to stay in a fridge for 40 minutes, now I can never come back again.

H-5fpXMrAfQ7VA22BnzkPA.text: Cool for what it is, but pricey for what it offers.It's an icebar, how can you not go and check it out!?  We just happened to be walking down Regent St. and decided to give it a go.  We came without reservations, so we had to wait about an hour before we could get in, which was okay with us.  The entrance price included a drink and 45 minutes in the bar, which sounded like a pretty good deal considering the average price of drinks was in that range.  Prior to entering, you get your cloak and mittens and then the rush is on.  If you've got a large group going in, expect for it to be a pain in the rear to try and get to the bar.  Apparently, certain people believe that once they order their drink, they can just stand in the same place at the bar and not move.  I don't fault the place for it, but it's definitely annoying.  The bar offers a small menu with many different types of drinks, as well as champagne (for an extra fee).  The drinks come in cool little ice glasses, but when you realize how much of the actual drink you get for the price, that's where the value drops.  It felt like I maybe had three spoon-sized samples of a drink. But hey, it is what it is.  Would I go back again?  Probably not unless with some friends that would have wanted to do it.  I do recommend to go and try it if you've never been.

tTZTKq9glr6d0_S2hYwweQ.text: Once you have the right expectations about the place, then you can fully enjoy this slightly campy but still neat tourist attraction.Booked tickets online to save a few pounds and arrived early, though there wasn't a huge crowd on a Monday night in September. Five minutes before your scheduled session, you will queue at the entrance. An employee will "cape" you with the famous hooded parkas you always see on Instagram, and then you enter the freezer.The tables, bar, walls, and glasses were all made of ice. Cool! You get one cocktail included in your entry price, which were delicious. I got the Turning Torso, which is a lychee flavored vodka cocktail, and my boyfriend got a gin drink. Both were excellent, though small in size. But in the end, you go to Icebar to experience winter wonderland, not to get the best cocktail deal anyway.There's a 40 minute limit which is more than enough to enjoy the surroundings. Even though I was wearing a sweater, jacket, and tights underneath the provided parka and gloves, my toes and fingers were getting numb after a half hour.Overall, I'd recommend this as a unique distraction from the rest of your typical London visit.

TXkD-6wFYFlJPVPGrFx28A.text: I was lucky enough to attend their galactic launch party, and i was impressed, i havent been before so was not entirely sure what to expect. After a few tequilla cocktails we were taken into the waiting area where we sampled a tequilla sorbet and a tequilla toothpaste concoction  very bizarre but lethal alcohol zing lol.I loved the outfits of the staff and the dj.We were given capes and gloves and sampled 2 coctails 1 blue 1 red and oh so nice. I even tried a sangrita ice lolly which was awful unfortunately someone took my pic showing my expression lol.I really enjoyed the novelty of this experience and look forward to going back and trying out one of their meal deals

nqrzDAY9R7tt6sjqU5_l-g.text: Recently, when I cornered a certain politician I needed to interrogate away from Parliamentary Privilege - where he had been protecting some of his controversial statements - this Bar/Restaurant was suggested. I will not voluntarily - but maybe under bright lights and a touch of water torture - give up my source as to who chose this rather 'opulent' rendezvous, other than to comment, that the suggestion was probably made hoping to 'cool' down any remarks I might make in my Newspaper Column.As an aside; I can't imagine many ordinary guys inviting a girl on a date to a place with a name like 'Below Zero.' Unless, of course, he was a chap who had spent time in an Igloo or perhaps was a relative of Sarah Palin - and maybe thought he had a 'cool chick' on his hands. Myself, if I was a guy and hoped that the date would lead to some nocturnal gymnastics afterwards, I think the name of the joint would have deterred me somewhat - I'd have chosen something more in keeping with 'Sweaty Palms', or 'High Voltage.' Maybe 'Nether Regions' would have been more appropriate for a hopeful Lothario.But, as they say, 'what's in name?' In this case it came down to 'What's in the Purse!' Frankly, it wasn't cheap, the booze was the same as you'd find in any classy establishment in town, although rather potent - which wasn't a bad thing, helped to get the old tongue to wag - and apart from the intimate and somewhat dark and plush interior - excellent for furtive foraging - the food was typically and tasty European. However, if you are someone of note, a celebrity or a crook on the run after a big heist, it's the perfect place not to be recognised. Methinks the Kray brothers would have loved the dark cavernous atmosphere. You could get out quickly and it would take the staff an hour at least to find the cold corpse.As for the staff, they were far from cool. Au Contraire. They were a delight and either that way because they could, snatch a quickie at the Ice Bar 'on the house,' or, were deliberately chosen for their personable warmth in order to increase the temperature because of the name of the place.They were more than charming to me - and I didn't even have to flash flesh to get a cherub smile every time a staff member actually found me - without having to use his torch in the dim interior.SUMMARY: Booze - hits the spot. Food far more than passable. Price decidedly heavy, but what else do you expect in Mayfair. Best factors: The décor, and the dark corners.A darling of a place for Spooks, Celebrities or Camera shy Parliamentarians.

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Salivating as I write!

jf7CbJ-dqEOtmuiCj4okXw.text: I went here with my boyfriend for our belated Valentines celebrations, on 18/2/15. We had a deal through Amazon Local for a cocktail in the icebar followed by dinner at the restaurant downstairs. We were given a warm poncho and gloves and then went inside. We were served quickly at the bar and had a choice of about a dozen cocktails served in a glass made of ice. A little bit of a strange feeling but not unpleasant. The room itself was a lot smaller than I thought with only space for about 10 people to sit down.  I didn't feel the cold much apart from on my feet as I was wearing open toed heels!!  We ended up leaving early (after about half an hour) as we had finished our drink and there wasn't much to do. There was a sculpture you could stand next to and a car to pose inside but little else. In all, I'm glad I went as it's something I can say I've done, but I wouldn't go back.

kKhykfMRUR4VDCVqbvAToA.text: Fantastic time had. The meal was fantastic. I had the monkfish for starter and then the flat iron steak. This was cooked perfectly and just melted in your mouth. The service was excellent, couldn't find fault. All the staff were lovely, happy and welcoming. Don't hesitate and just go. Can't wait to go again.

zIcBCceMc1XTlUdCn-rtNw.text: I had wanted to check out an ENTIRE BAR MADE OF ICE since my Grandmother got to go to one in another country (Stockholm?). So, while in London we found the Absolut Icebar and were really excited.You walk in and they put these huge warm coats on you. There's gloves too. Then they give you a token for a free drink! You walk through the little anteroom and suddenly it is freezing! Everything is ice! The walls are made out of ice. The chairs are made out of ice. The bar is made out of ice. The glasses are made out of ice. Okay, you get the picture. We tried a bunch of fun drinks including my favorite which was a strawberry and cream concoction.I really liked that outside of the ice area there is a normal bar room where you can order some appetizers and have drinks while your fingers thaw- Note: your fingers will only need to thaw if you kept taking off your gloves to touch everything. So, Absolut Icebar is this very fun place that you probably will go to once and enjoy but not frequent every Friday as it is a little pricey and touristy.

ibXGayJcaFzUv8a6VNChwQ.text: Very cute theme and idea but the venue lost its appeal after all of 3 minutes. Still worth checking out though. And once is enough. The cocktails were acceptable - try the apollo 11, avoid zero gravity.

Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom

gs9c6TDFHGJQsDsEyNovxA.text: Probably will not be venturing back here.  Just wasn't my cup of tea.The concept is that they have this place in freezing temperatures and they give you this giant poncho to wear over your clothes.  Gloves are provided and you just go in.  You have to make a reservation for a specific time to go, and you only have 45 minutes inside of the fridge.  It was more than enough time for my friends and I to claim our two drinks, drink them, and leave.  We also arrived late.It's just a weird mix of people... in the sense that you can't SEE any of them.  Sort of felt like a cult meeting.  All you could see are bobbing coned heads all of the place.  I just think it would be a weird place to mingle.Check it out though... worth experiencing just once!

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Brr

D8drXqlHMWPdMyby5WF0QA.text: I had a friend visiting, so after reading reviews thought that this might be a fun thing to do. The buildup was great- we booked our reservation on-line, waited for our 2 minute group info session before being cloaked in a poncho and being sent off into the ice box. But even with the anticipation it was just okay, and here's why-Drinks- Very tasty and very strong, though a bit small...Decor- I thought there would be more to it. The blocks of ice that make up the wall have been carved internally, which makes sense but wasn't as cool as I had imagined (this was obviously my fault; I was let down because it just didn't match up to what I thought they could have done).Staff- Very friendly but after a couple drinks there, that just wasn't enough to hold my attention so we took off. Good drinks, but I probably won't be going back.**Side note, bring cash! The CC machine doesn't work inside the bar

8BZVQ2uU6yMb7v_Lypqc9A.text: I actually can not believe this place is still going, but I guess it's all about tourists, which we all know equals people-traffic!I went for a friends birthday. Not something I personally would choose, but it was interesting nonetheless. The birthday girl had a good time, so I was happy.Can't really justify the price for what you get though, and in effect you're paying to stand in a freezer for 30 or so minutes. I remember in my days of working for M&S, girls were only aloud in the big freezer for a short time, as we were told our ovaries would freeze! Nice! Yet some how they manage to get us to pay for the pleasure? Ha! Well apparently if you wrap it up with a pretty bow you can sell anything to anyone... don't you just love advertising!

or3j--AxibHY95ymtSKSIA.text: Very fun experience! If you go, make sure you wear SHOES and not slippers. Friend wore slippers and that was just a bad idea. haha. I've never been to an ice bar so the experience was worth it. Love the drinks in the ice cups and the tables and chairs made of ice. The jackets you have to wear make you feel like your in another world like an eskimo. It ads to the appeal of the place. I don't know if I'd come here again since it's pricey, but I definitely recommend it if you have never been before. Definitely worth the experience with friends.

5VHi39tTb3AtlMqYsNVxzA.text: I saw the Ice Bar on a website when I was planning a trip to London so booked online before we went which saved a bit of money I think. We had a lot of trouble finding it as it's not on the main road and didn't know our way around so were almost late! I really enjoyed it, it was great for taking photos and looking around but I didn't think the actual drinks were very nice. I chose a baileys type of thing and it seemed to have curdled a bit in the ice glass as there were weird lump bits in it so it wasn't that nice. Also the staff are a bit arrogant and desperate for you to go to the restaurant which I found a bit irritating.

FxXaCH-SG9Ic4EmwLoQqFQ.text: I liked it... good fun and nice experience. One-time have to see evening... Cooling down in the middle of the melting pot London. Chilly, drinking from ice-glasses, vodka is king and nothing but ice around you. Nothing for claustrophobia people I would assume as room appears small in my eyes. 30 minutes staying time max if you wear business dress... ;-)

6IqrphB90JLg6DrPPMf_Qw.text: Funny, I was just about to review this place when Whitney beat me to it in a matter of minutes.  I will proceed with my reviewing nonetheless.I have to agree that this place is just, well average.  Okay, their cocktails were pretty damn interesting.  I had a lychee loveboat (or some similarly named drink) that consisted of lychee vodka, lychee juice, lemongrass, and chili as well as eye of newt and tusk of wild boar.  The resulting concoction was pretty tasty.  Beyond this drink, however, was a world of possibility floundered into unremarkability. (Yes, I know I made that word up).  The service was somewhat unserviceable.  The decor lacked character - a lounge with big, sleek leather seats - ooooh original.  The cocktails were between 7 and 12 pounds.  The cockatiels either didn't exist or didn't chirp out tunes of joy.  Or, the might have frozen in the connected Ice Bar.  That would be sad.There's better lounges in this city, but this one will do if you feel like throwing down a 20 and having an average experience, no cockatiels and only cocktails expected.

lhYJU8VO_dv0rvVX-FeEpA.text: Same atmosphere as the one in Stockholm Sweden. DON'T forget to bring your jacket, or if they offer you a robe, take it!The surroundings is elegant and icee. Quite a place for a group of friends to hangout for a few hours, have a few drinks. Combo and discount packages might be a good idea

uXdduEcVzZ4C0r-fFYVF8w.text: Walking in on ground floor level there are two bars - a normal bar and ofcourse the ice bar. Having to wear a foil thermal cape felt a bit space like but obviously was necessary to survive the sub zero temperatures. It did seem insane leaving the cold weather outside to venture into an even colder bar but as it was a private function the free bar was very tempting. I figured that the free vodka shots (served in glasses made of ice) would quickly make me forget that I was in a minus 5 degrees bar. Even though I took full advantage of the free bar I still could not forget how cold I felt. This is probably why staff allow a maximum of 40 minutes in the Ice Bar. The Ice Bar is certainly a cool bar although the usual admission fee of £15 seems a bit steep for 40 minutes in the cold!Definately a great (and freezing) experience!

ohfM9Eoql_m9xD4DIGoCxQ.text: I was really excited to try out this place, as how great would it be to drink drinks in sub- zero temperatures (kept at minus 5 degrees all year round!), and kept warm with gloves and apparently a 'designer thermal cape' - which might I add made me feel like I was dressing to go on some venture to outer-space.Everything form the bar to the glasses you drink out of are made out of ice. I have to say, it is definitely worth a visit just for the experience. But at £12  for a 40 minute slot from Sunday to Wednesday, or £15 from Thursday to Saturday, it is just far too expensive a place to constantly frequent. You do get a Vodka cocktail along with the entrance fee, but then to have another will be £6 pounds. As already stated, it is worth a try, but I have to say, despite the initial excitement prior to my visit, I wasn't completely wowed by the place. N.B: from the 24th November, expect the entry price to rise from £12 to £12.50 and £15 to £16.

N6SYKvgjQidBj993XQwGtg.text: The ice bar is just off regent street down heddon street, to be honest it doesnt look too inviting from the outside but once inside it gets better.It costs £12 each for 20 minutes in the ice bar which includes one drink. (a very sugary cocktail in an ice glass any extra drinks are at a further cost)20 minutes are enough as it is very cold despite the cloak and gloves given to you to wear.When we went there were around 30 people all in the same group and it did feel quite crowded. Its good to do something different and outsid ethe bar there are other bars to relax and warm up in.

xxSZz7I1wLlESVTnBznSsA.text: I think this is a good experience for what it is. You get to wear a fancy thermal cloak and big gloves which keeps you warm. To be dressed like that is entertainment value in itself. You get one free drink on arrival. (vodka mixes hence Absolut). Note, the drinks are poured into ice cube glasses. So you're drinking from ice. There are ice seats and scultures around. Everything is Ice, the bar everything. You are in there for 20 mins only, so enjoy the experience whilst it lasts! It is -5 degrees all year round. It is a little on the pricey side but worth it.

ICag1NEYqnE3NVgvAWOmUg.text: It is definitely a must do if you are visiting London.  The bar is entirely made of ice.  Make sure that you go on the website and book a time to go in especially if you are going on a Thursday, Friday, or Saturday.  You get about 40 minutes in there so use your time wisely.  The drinks are not that big so if you done a few it is definitely worth it.  They give these hug jackets and gloves so that you do not get cold.  They also have a photographer on site that will take your picture.  The atmosphere is great and the bartenders are friendly.  It is definitely a good way to start off your night and then go out afterwards.  If anything go there to say you have been.  I mean how may people can say they have been to a bar completely made of ice?

I-5Erqr-9Oj5LclwM1rrxg.text: Good way to start a night out, definitely something different to do in the heart of London. You are provided with gloves and winter overcoat before you go into the small icebar for drinks. They have tried to make the room interesting with a couple of small ice sculptures and etchings but it does begin to drag a bit unless you are in a large group. Nice start to the night if you are going to a nice restaurant near Regents Street afterwards.

g6Cc4-N_5GdTPl7vNQpnYA.text: The Ice Bar is one of those things that you do so that you can say you've done it. You never want to hear someone say Have you been to the Ice Bar? and then have no come back! I visited the Ice Bar as part of my company Christmas party last year, and I'd highly recommend it (partly because I didn't have to foot the ridiculous bill!). You get a 45 minute slot (trust me, it seems a lot longer), and a metallic blue hooded cape to keep you warm while you're inside. Once your group is together you get herded into a small, rather disappointing ice-walled room. Don't expect an icy maze to lose yourself in! Barmen serve a very limited selection of over-priced cocktails in thick ice glasses. None of this matters. If you're lucky enough to go with a good group of people it'll be a great evening. You'll spend 45 minutes laughing about how silly the whole thing is and taking pictures of your friends in their silly cloaks. The regular bar in the same building is a great way to spend time after your 45 minutes are over. The cocktail selection is great, if a little pricey.

xGVYBuboeuf4B7HC6-HJpA.text: The Ice Bar was freezing, they give you big coats to wear with hoods and boy do you need them. You go through to a smallish room entirely made out of ice including the bar, walls, seats and tables. Its all pretty cool and a complete novelty! You are handed an ice cube glasses and you can have any drink on the absolute vodka menu. They are a bit sickly but good if you are getting drunk. You only have 30 mins in the place but you don't want any longer as it gets very cold. All in all an interesting experience for a special occasion.

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom

21AyxnIMWk9KRHA6kTY1bg.text: The Absolut vodka ice bar is well overrated in my opinion. My experience there was quite boring due mainly to the fact that the prices are so high and the 'ice bar' in itself is quite small and uncomfortable. The experience is unique but I felt quite ripped off for the £12 I had to pay to get in which did include the drinks but were quite difficult to actually drink from in small blocks of ice with a scooped out hole in the middle. Overpriced and overrated.

Vy11-ZvKfX0n1dTnmWp8ZQ.text: The Ice Bar is a must go, at least for its originality. Everything from the bar stools to the glasses is made of crystal clear ice. Also, it's a vodka bar, so all vodka amateurs will appreciate the large choice of vodka cocktails. Honestly, it's not the kind of place that you want to attend on a regular basis but it's fun and worth your while.

oL6DLcNKtP_o2LGHv7fI3w.text: Admittedly I have not been inside the icy part of the Ice Bar, just drunk wine and had dinner. The food to be honest is nothing to rave about, quite small portions and expensive for what they were. Maybe I just should have gone in the actual icy bit.

wnhHKcgUJUedHtoliSdxZw.text: I expected the ice bar to be icy but didn't realise the walls, bar, tables, and even your personal glass would be made of ice! The Icebar runs in 45 minute time slots, so yu need to call first and book a slot. Upon your arrival you will be given a cape (complete with mittens) to keep you warm for your visit. Once inside, the ice bar itself is quite small and surprisingly cosy, with lots of sculptures and crazy seats and stools to look at. The bar is reconstructed with a completely new design every six months and so repeat visits can still be fun and interesting. After your 45 minutes has flown by you can warm up downstairs in a cosy log cabin-like environment, where there's also a delicious menu  perfect for winter nights! -They do the occasional Burlesque themed night here too, which are a real giggle and well worth checking out!

lPwAHFAOCfgQ6iu4v_xBlg.text: so this is pretty much a place you should go to once, and probably never again. we thought it was a place that you'd need reservations, but we came in early evening and got in with no problem. we were actually the only ones there aside from a group of four people huddled in the corner, shivering in their eskimo gear. i'll admit, the room is cool. the room is also small. you get one free absolut drink with your admission, and the drinks, although pretty good, were fairly weak. there are only so many times you can walk to the ice couch or the ice chair until it gets a little boring. we stayed and had about three additional drinks before we left, 30 minutes into our stay because my feet were becoming numb from the cold. fun, but only for about 10 minutes.

b0-oEZSxRVlGk8tHP0ooLQ.text: Yes, I went to the ultimate tourist trap!  I admit it.  But I have to admit, We had a great time.  After you get over the horror of shelling out 15 pounds for a cover charge, you get to put on cool looking eskimo suits and drink from glasses made of ice.  However, I did not know what was in those ice glasses but whatever it was, it kept me nice and warm inside.  This is probably not a place I will go on my next trip to London but it was a great experience.

SIhkNikhm3o1br4qwuy0Ww.text: Very nice bar, the perfect place to start a night party

ynXXgGb3-G6CIIMSd79N5Q.text: The concept behind this place is super cool. And it's a fun experience to have at least once but I really think that's all you really need, because the novelty of the igloo theme wears off rather quickly. We had to wear the capes, which were somewhat weighty and difficult to move around in. They serve you the drinks in frozen glasses, which seem neat for aesthetic purposes but don't tend to help your case of frost bite. We were in there for about 15-20 min before we were freezing and decided to leave.

q7e3ebkFDioMMlQprmh1rw.text: I bought a deal on Groupon which was a better value for money than just walking in. Cocktails are not very expensive, but the "experience" seemed to be. However  the ice area is really cool...I mean literally. Luckily they provide an antifreeze blanket with gloves-maybe that's why the cost. But make sure you have more than a t-shirt on you. The ice glasses are crazy slippery and cold, cocktails and service are good with pleasant and smiley staff. I feel for the bartender in the ice area as his heater is out of order.The warm bar area is very nice,elegant,relaxing and has a great decor. It was a great night there.

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Lady in warm...
Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Lady in ice
Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. The skull seat

3ek1CRJdQC2qQfDX2MyGkg.text: We started our evening in the bar downstairs which was very cosy and chalet-like drinking extremely delicious prosecco based cocktails which went down far too easily. Upon arrival everyone had been given a colour coded wristband which determined which time we would enter the actual ice bar room. The room is quite small but really well laid out and you can also only stay for a maximum of 45 minutes due to the fact that it's -5 degrees in there! Don't worry though, you're given a cosy cape and gloves before you enter to keep you warm.Every year the IceBar closes for a week for a revamp when several tonnes of Swedish ice is flown in and carved by an expert team. This year's theme is IceBar rocks.The first thing that caught my eye was the giant skulls adorning the room. But every wall was carved with some of the most intricate of designs my favourite being the tattooed rock chick whose sleeve housed many famous rock stars within it.The bar was one of my favourite things about the whole experience. Not just the fact that they sold epic cocktails (you all know my soft spot for cocktails and the list is quite impressive here, it took me a while to decide) but the fact that all of the drinks are sold in glasses made from actual ice. Your first cocktail is even included in the cost of your ticket which makes the cost (standard tickets start from £13.50 per person) great value given the novelty value and central location in my opinion.

ztl8pph2YRhdIKqrdGM-Bg.text: Had difficulty reviewing this place in my mind. Was it cool and unique? Ya. Was it worth the money? Maybe. Would I recommend it as a must see in London? No. With so much to see and do in London, this place doesn't have a ton to offer. The site made it seem like the bar was huge and included some type of tour and explanation of how ice sculptures are created. Nope. Disappointed by how tiny the place was! It was literally a bar, handful of seats, and two random sculptures of a pineapple and cupcake lol. So once you're inside, there isn't a lot to do, you're just standing around. I also though the drinks would be individually crafted given that the descriptions before entering the bar seemed very elaborate. Nope. All premade. Disappointed. Also really small drinks. The 14 pounds includes a drink and the jacket/gloves at least. I heard the sponsored ice bars are way cooler (Absolut/Smirnoff) so I would do that instead. This place was really just for the cool factor/cool pics.

8r7chloqF2rNMtkpDpqYxA.text: I have had a horrible experience with Icebar. I have three friends visiting from another country, and we had booked tickets for the 4 of us at Icebar. I have come down with a serious case of the flu the day of my booking. I called to see if I could be accommodated in any way considering that the price for entry and one drink is rather steep. They were extremely UNhelpful. They would not let me move my reservation to another day and leave my friends tickets as the same, and they would not give me a refund of any sort. Terrible customer service.

jGvgI0-5f9zNIkNuJ5Pu_Q.text: Yeah, yeah. Who comes to London and doesn't go to the ICEBAR?Not me!We did this on our first night we moved to London. Honestly. After throwing our bags into our flats straight from Heathrow, we changed clothes and headed straight for the Absolut ice bar. The wait took awhile, but the waiting lounge is really lovely, and if you're with friends, you won't mind one bit. We decided to save our p's for once we got into the igloo part and didn't order drinks while waiting.When it's your turn, they throw the special blue cloaks on you along with a pair of wicked mittens. Then it's time to booze and ice skate for the time you have inside. Basically, you take lots of shots -- in ice glasses and with your camera holding, touching, or sitting on other ice objects.Anyone bitching about the price obviously missed the point. This is not your corner pub, it's a novelty attraction. Is admission to a theme park equal to your bus fare?

5Yxq4c4-YetBFLwcvdEFwQ.text: One a kind experience!After making reservations, we came here to get a drink in the IceBar. Arrived a few minutes prior to our reservation time. They group a bunch of people together based on the reservation time. They put a huge jacket around you and let you into the IceBar. A semi-circle bar with chairs and tables around. Colorful lights everywhere and music to which you could happily dance to, especially after a drink. Even the drink cup is made of ice. Pretty cool eh?One cocktail comes along with the $$ you paid for the reservations. Extra charges for additional drinks. I ordered a Victorian Sour and my husband, a Googie. Both were really good!There is a 40 minutes timer inside and you get to do whatever you want inside the ice bar. Feeling too cold? - You can step outside. Else, no rush. Just enjoy!A drink in your hand, a good company and music - Bliss! Just make sure you come in with a covered shoe or sandals.

7WP0n-_SJ-bMy_6rmWcluw.text: This place was awesome. We went into the actual IceBar to have drinks. You're given a thermal cloak with gloves attached to stay warm and also hold your glass for drinks since your glass is made out of ice. It is very cold inside (-5 degrees Celsius) and I had on thin pants so my knee caps were cold lol! It's a cool experience and the drinks are very very good! My husband and I both had the drinks, Chop Suey, as a recommendation from the bartender and were not disappointed. They were tasty. We then had More than a Feeling drinks which featured the bar's champagne. Two thumbs up!! Well four in our case!

Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. The ice made glasses we got to have our drinks out of.

ShNaQQEGwsB9sCNcysC_CA.text: Admittedly, I was a tourist being a tourist and when I saw the icebar being recommended on the guidebook I thought, "this is too COOL to pass up!" Literally. Everything inside this bar is made of ice: walls, seats, tables and the bar itself. Entrance is pricey at £14 and this buys you one REALLY girly drink. The cocktail menu has a lot of vodka based drinks, all of which feature Absolut vodka. My cosmo was really sweet, so I wouldn't go here to get smashed. Before entering the bar, you're given thermal hooded cloaks with matching gloves, and believe me my friend you will use those gloves to hold your drink since your cocktail is served on a block of ice! neato!There's a big digital timer on the wall to signal your 40 minute time limit inside the bar. (who stays there longer anyway?!) If you've never been, go to satisfy your curiosity and have a blast!* For cold-weather lover Janet O *

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Cosmopolitan served in a block of ice

mldf-DoV8ajDKG7SGsWfCA.text: Quite a cool one off experience. The cocktails were darn nice. Shame they appeared to just be pre-mixed syrups, but understandable as the experience is only 40 minutes and there are at least that many to serve the complimentary cocktail as part of the experience.As you arrive, you're thrown into a very bulky poncho, which comfortably fits over any sort of backpack you might have. Next you move into the ice bar itself. A interesting small room, that situated within, is a bar, a few tables and seats. It's cold, but not that cold. I think it must have only been about -2/-3.Decor wise there is a lot of photograph, but very little to appreciate. You'll understand once there. There aren't any interesting details carved into the nice. There isn't any history or ice or any special sculptures. Your drink is served in an ice glass, which is cool, but gimicky. Other than the decor itself, there isn't really any effort on behalf of either the staff to provide any entertainment or banter. The whole "keep your glass" if you want to order another drink was a little cheeky personally. If you're buying another tiny cocktail, I wouldn't they they would scrimp of the cost of some frozen water.In all, one of those places to tick off the bucket list. I did enjoy my time there. But not enough to recommend to others. If you're already thinking about it though, it's likely worth your time.

kjQQ_xCTUz1BtdMcmYRy5g.text: Chill out and knock one back below zero. I've been twice and while this is no place to get pissed, it's a blast of a good time. I've seen couples, birthdays and corporate parties book ICEBAR. It's a novelty with imported ice from Sweden and imported guests from all over the world and right here from river city. It's not all tourists. The drinks are not strong but you have your choice of vodka, rum, whiskey and tequila in addition to uncharged champagne. Well booze is quite fine or you can upgrade to premium for £4 more. Not really worth is since the drinks are weak. At least they're not watered down with melted ice.Book on line and enjoy your time freezing your arse off. It's a blast!

G3bA4OsIr_QAuFLtw8oaxg.text: Sorry for all the negative experience from others, but i had lots of fun at this place. you see, we first started out with a tapas and champagne dinner elsewhere. Later, we decide to walk around the city to find something else to do for fun. Then we stumbled into the ice hotel on a rather warm night. For us, there was 0 wait. WE had no idea what to expect. We paid for our admissions and was thrown on some cheezy fake fur clothes. We then got shipped into an ice bar where we had some average vodka base cocktails in an ice shot glass. I wouldn't say it's recommended, must go type of venue... but if you are looking for something silly to do after when you and your buddies are slightly tipsy, it's great fun for pictures and laugh. Should go at least once to check it out if you live in London.

uuM-OIL4oRGxUOmlihzhqQ.text: This place was very unique! Eveything was made out of ice! What I loved most was how the shots came inside this ice cube thing which made the drinks taste even better! It was really cold so that's why they limit it to a 45 min session but it was really fun and a must do in London

XockZmugSRXJY5w4PdhChQ.text: The ice bar is one of those 'must visit once' places.For me it was on a  friends hen do- we were apprehensive we wouldn't be let in as we were late but after consulting they ushered us in only saying that we wouldn't get extra time at the end.You are provided with a thick insulated cloak clock and mittens before being ushered into the ice bar itself.Astounding to see a bar, tables everything made of ice! ! Cocktails come in an ice glass!! A great novelty but has to be said not fantastic for those of us with sensitive teeth! We didn't feel the lack of our time there- to be honest there's not a lot to do once you've had a couple of drinks and gone round taking masses of photos! I was however a bit disappointed that when the clock on the wall counting down to the end of the session hits 5 minutes that's when the lights come on and everyone is politely reminded it's nearly time to go - instant atmosphere killer.Overall I wouldn't bother to go back (been there done that sort of feeling ) but as a one off experience I was really glad to have tried it!!

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom

pM0oz-_jQq_4NhpZTeVGWg.text: One Friday night myself and the chap took a wander over to Heddon Street, just off Regent Street, to experience the ICEBAR.  For the chap this was his first time in London and I hadn't been in a good three years so the design was totally new.  I'd been mega excited about this all day as I knew we'd be having a decent night ahead!On arrival we joined the queue where we were given out tickets and second drink passes.  The staff were bloody awesome, so very polite and it really felt like they enjoyed their jobs which I feel can be quite rare in bars and venues now days! They were very hospitable, whisking the chaps backpack away and donning us in those super stylish capes.The theme of the ICEBAR is frozen food and I love it!! The bar was a frozen goods truck and around the room was a frozen pineapple you were able to have your photo taken in plus a rather delicious looking cupcake!We both tried different cocktails; I opted for the Tropical Sensation that was made up from Absolut Blue Vodka, Blueberry Liqueur, Tropical Fruit Juice, Lemon Juice, and Strawberry Syrup.  It taste so summery so it was certainly an odd feeling with being so cold whilst drinking it!  The chap went for the Blue Blazer that was made up from Four Roses Bourbon, Blue Curacao Liqueur, Ginger Ale, and Lemon Juice, and he loved it!  We had the same cocktails second time around which was a little naughty as we should of tried the others but these were too good to not have again!Once our 40 minute session had come to an end we lined up to get rid of those capes; I'm not gonna lie I'd so own my own one for winter months!We had such a great experience inside the ICEBAR that we decided to continue our night in the warm bar. The cocktail menu is pretty damn impressive and I had to try the Purple Rain concoction.  It was made up of Absolut Kurant vodka, Triple sec liqueur, Crème de Mure liqueur, blackberry puree, and lime juice.  The chap isn't a huge fan of cocktails so he went for a Jamieson Whisky and Diet Coke.Once again, the staff were great. I have to say our experience was so enjoyable I can certainly see us going back once they change the ice again, which brings me on to some awesome facts about the ICEBAR...Everything inside the ICEBAR is made out of crystal clear ice harvested especially from the frozen Torne River in Jukkasjärvi, Northern Sweden.  This is due to how clear the water is, and once you've seen how amazing the ice is inside the ICEBAR you'll totally understand why they bring it over all that way!  They bring specialist sculptors over for 5 days to work on the designs you see, and this happens once a year.  Every three months they pop back over again to renew the tables and chairs as they get a fair bit of wear and tear!

ty-xKM29pE1ogG465aQz5Q.text: Go here for the experience, but expect nothing more.They should really work on their crowd management. It was impossible to get around the room since large groups of tourist or immature college students kept crowding the sculptures in the middle and would not move. Then there are the groups that hog all the seats and tables. It's very much a "tourist destination," so they're just doing the bare minimum to meet a mediocre satisfaction from customers.It's a nice experience, though. I also went around Christmastime, so the Christmassy sculptures made a special impression.

VdTXFN16gOtdYtWUwT90hA.text: My parents bought my tickets for the Ice Bar as a Christmas present. I had wanted to go for years and it turned out to be a great day out!The queue was a bit of a buzz kill, but nothing a bottle of wine can't fix! We were given our blue capes and ushered away into the freezing ice bar with a large group of people. It was smaller than I had anticipated, but much better decor than I imagined. They had a globe sculpted out of ice and the glasses were made of ice too! The 40 minutes inside was enough, before I started shivering uncontrollably. Downside: Pricey drinks, little quantity and weak measures but expected from the heart of London I guess.Verdict: A must-do touristy attraction in the city!

ZUW4SW5OmWhuqrefxf1KKg.text: Although my original travel plan to Stockholm got completely ruined by the blizzard and a series of flight cancellations, I got to experience a little bit of Stockholm while being stranded in London! It truly made my day, what a fun experience that was! So gimmicky and touristie but this is definitely a must visit!!!! It turned out to be the coolest bar, literally!!!I found Absolute Icebar by pure coincidence. I just happened to stumble across the bar while roaming around the Heddon St., and I got so excited that there's an Icebar in London as well! I asked the bouncer how the system works, and he told me the cover charge is 16GBP/ person which includes 1 drink price and the guests are allocated 45 minutes slots inside the Icebar. And trust me, you wouldn't want to stay any longer than 45 minutes because it's -5°C inside!! The interior is all made of ice, and visually stunning with cool colorful lightings. The space is rather small, but there are enough unique visual interests to keep your eyes entertained. Even the cocktails are served in glasses made of ice, but the size is very small. The atmosphere is very hip and tasteful, decorated with funky ice sculptures, definitely worth going at least once for the novelty experience of it!
