AOKUVXvNoNMkHfQK58xj2w.text: This is kind of a "must do" bar experience when you're visiting London.   Short walk from Picadilly Circus...make a reservation first online as each session is approx 45 minutes.  When your time is up you get a nice cape and with some gloves and you enter a magnificent ice bar.  Even the glasses you drink out of are solid ice...they play some hip EDM music so you can dance away while freezing your ass off.  45 minutes is plenty and as always it depends who you are with in regards to how much fun you have!  Enjoy!

kfXv6wlLfjoSsNUQmxbGQw.text: We were invited to the YUC (Yelp unofficial community) launch at the Ice Bar and were given an awesome time. Ice bar were excellent hosts and the bite sized food was great, especially the cheese ball croquets (highly recommend). We also were treated to two fantastic cocktails, the blackberry crumble (tasted just like a proper crumble and included the crumbs on top) and a prescco & vodka cocktail (highly refreshing). The Ice bar itself was, as expected, cold! However, the coats and gloves keep us warm enough to enjoy a cocktail served in a glass made out of ice. I had the sucker punch, a run based cocktail, and it did not disappoint. The ice carvings are great and are most certainly worth a quick selfie or, if you can, a group shot. Apparently the theme changes once a year so return visit are a good consideration. Finally, when you're not chilling away inside the ice bar there is a Mini-Club-like space downstairs for guests to thaw out in and also dance away to return the warmth.

0jWbfiugYqMu5KmYEWZbOQ.text: Its been a while ice bar!I've been to this bar 3 times now. The first time I spent new year's eve here 2010 and had the time of my life. The second occasion was pleasant but I was more sober and the cold had me all shook up lol.Third occasion  was last night and I was a little bored by it all frankly.I'm aware that they change the theme of the bar yearly but this theme was lacking in excitement for me. lGsUY_0vKp7QkeWBbFopsA.text: My friend and I went to london for the May bank holiday and we looked for different places to eat and drink. As the ice bar was close to China town we decided to go. When we got there, there was a queue to the door, so we joined it. A member of staff with a clipboard asked if we had a booking which we didn't .. And told us there was space if we came back at 8.15pm, as it wasn't 7pm yet, we pondered on what to do. So we got back in the queue, as she also said speak to reception to see if we could still get in. They have time slots and depending on when people leave the ice bar, as you need to wear the cape and gloves. They only have 30 capes, so up to 30 people go in at a time. Reception said we could go in but will have missed 10 mins, as you get an hour in the bar for the £16 entry fee! So we paid!You wear the cape and go through double doors and go up to the bar where you choose a cocktail as one is included, the rest you pay for. You must wear the gloves to handle the ice glasses! I had s cocktail similar to mojito and it was really nice, could had more! Inside there are sculptures and some seating at the back, but it's cramped with groups of people trying to move round is hard! I could see some people had their shopping bags with them so would been better if they had put into a cloakroom. There is a photographer in there but we didn't have one taken, we just used our own phones. We didn't stay long as my friend wasn't very well so we left within our time slot, so we had done it! Though I had been to an ice bar in Warsaw few years ago!You can eat at the restaurant here though it's not in a ice bar!! I think they accept the tastecard for a discount on food! If you decide to visit the ice bar, book in advance to save all the queuing etc!!!

qWUMv_TexnsLf6CkMJH5jQ.text: IceBar London is somewhere that's always been on my bucket list of places to go but never quite got around to. In case you've never heard of it - imagine a bar where pretty much everything (walls, bar, glasses) is made out of pure ice.The first thing I noticed entering the bar was the HUGE skull scuplture next to the bar area itself - and you can actually climb inside and peer out from the eyes! At the bar, we were served champagne in glasses actually made from ice (which is where the gloves attached to the poncho definitely make sense) - you can also order yourself a drink from a range of tasty rock-inspired cocktails.I was so impressed with the level of detail that went into the designs - from the tattooed 'rock chick' on the wall to the bar decorated with punky studs - and one of the feature pieces and a total photo opportunity was the Throne of Rock. The blue and purple lighting was wonderfully atmospheric and really emphasised the ice as the light caught and reflected around the room.I did have to pop out for a little bit during the visit to warm up (I'm a ridiculously temperature-sensitive person!), but the temperature in IceBar London is definitely easily manageable for the 40 minute time slot you get and you warm up super quickly afterwards (especially if you pop on a 'wine jacket'). Definitely a quirky night out to show the out-of-towners why London (and Ice Bar) rocks.

Ib18yBqkg6pR4pKBcrQKCw.text: Was walking around the streets when my local friend told me of this place, and I've always wanted to go to Icebar so I said why not? 6lEdBciWeV43jV4K42Tj7w.text: Icebar is pretty much what it says on the tin - a bar made of ice. Cold, -5°C Swedish ice, to be precise.We got kitted out in thermal capes and gloves, and were served cocktails served in glasses made entirely of ice - it was awesome.The walls, the chairs, the bar - everything was ice, and had been carved beautifully. My favourite part was the skull, which had a brain carved into it and everything!For the price of a ticket, you get given a cocktail and can stay in the room for 45 minutes before you have to leave. Is it gimmicky? Yes, absolutely - but it is really fun, and you do feel surprisingly toasty in your thermal cape.

9yW9KY-4bOPMVBrKPxCaNg.text: As a Londoner, I dismissed the Icebar as a novelty aimed primarily at tourists. As a Canadian, I eschewed it because huddling for warmth in an icebox- and paying for the pleasure- was distinctly unappealing. However, I was recently given the opportunity to experience both the Icebar and restaurant. We've had anything but a conspicuous winter this year and my tolerance for sub-zero temperatures was high- so I took the icy plunge.Upon arrival to the Icebar, visitors are provided with a thermal hooded cape to drape over their shoulders- it's weighty and slightly restrictive, but provides an effective layer of warmth. Bulky mittens are attached to the cape by a cord, but it's impossible to take the requisite photographs with your hands burried in these sheaths. The Icebar itself is a small room where all surfaces are- wait for it- carved from ice. There are some tables and seats, but you'll be lured in by the overtly Instagrammable décor, with features such as imposing skull-shaped ice sculptures, for a plethora of photograph opportunities.Visitors are granted a 40 minute timeslot to take in the frosty surroundings and select a cocktail from a decent menu. The atmosphere is vibrant and the room is dimly lit with plenty of backlighting to emphasise the ice fixtures. An energetic background soundtrack is also provided. It is all a bit of a laugh and something that you'll likely not need to do more than once.After the visit to the Icebar, we were guided downstairs to the restaurant. Staff were organised and we were immediately seated in a quiet corner in the back, giving us a prime vista to admire the surroundings. The setting is surprisingly informal and spacious, with hints of alpine-inspired touches and some private booths lined up against the walls. We were comfortable dressed in jeans and the staff were hospitable, chatty and attentive. We had a particularly charming server who was well-versed in the menu and delivered a complimentary bowl of moreish gordal olives to our table before our starters arrived.The food is relatively uncomplicated and the menu focuses on seasonal ingredients- all at a reasonable price for a central London venue. Upon recommendation of our server, I was swayed by the cured salmon and my boyfriend needed no persuasion to order the slow roast pork ribs. My only grievance was the portion size of the salmon, a sparing cut of fish accompanied with a sprinkling of lime caviar and chopped hazelnuts. It melted in the mouth and I could've happily devoured two more servings. The ribs, conversely, arrived in a more generous abundance to much praise from my boyfriend.Our mains didn't disappoint: the slow cooked stone bass came with the most delicious crushed potatoes that I've ever had, rich and freckled with thyme. The fish was perfectly cooked and delicately served, left to be savoured without an overly dominant sauce. The pickled kohlrabi gave an acidic flavour that resulted in a beautifully harmonious plate. The rump steak, a special on the evening, arrived stacked with a grilled meaty mushroom, glazed shallots finished with a drizzling of a rich jus. We had no room for desert, but did share a bottle of wine from their drinks menu, which had a good range of fairly reasonably priced wines.So, even if you do bypass the frivolous fun of the Icebar itself, the restaurant is a pleasant surprise. It offers a casual and relaxed atmosphere for a relatively reasonable price for central London where you won't feel rushed or encroached upon other diners.  You'll also feel looked after by the waiting staff, who were exceptional during our visit.  As a standalone, the restaurant is definitely a solid contender for a good quality meal out in the city. But why wouldn't you want to make a night of it and stick your face through an ice sculpture?

JrrWr72IdBH6inkB8SHypA.text: My friend was visiting London and she wanted to go to the Icebar so I went along.  The first thing I would recommend is wearing decent footwear and a large coat!!! Flats will not do the job, and your shoes will stick to the ground making it difficult to walk around!The bar itself is actually quite small, although that's quite alright considering that it's completely made out of ice.  You get one free drink in a cup made of ice, and you're asked to keep your cup if you decide to buy another drink.I believe the allocated time is 45 minutes, but you really only need about 30 minutes (maybe less) to enjoy this place.I'm not sure if I would put this on the 'Top 10' things to do in London if you're visiting as a tourist, but if you happen to go, it's kind of fun.

aHQtece4dI3JCzx5BZsIWw.text: Was a nice experience however the music wasn't great and the room itself was very small and the drinks were overpriced, was a nice addition to an evening however I don't think it's something to do more than once

SHDttr320e_L0UmynlPbHw.text: When I discovered the Icebar while looking for fun things to do in London, I knew we had to give it a try!First, it is important to note that their restaurant doesn't open until about 3 or 4 for food. You can start your tour of the Icebar at around 2 PM on a weekday. We bought two tickets for about 30 pounds. The ticket comes with a free cocktail and then 40 minutes in the Icebar (which is way longer than you need to be in there). I ordered the Pineapple Express, which was delicious. The serving was a little small, but it comes in a glass that is made entirely out of ice, which was cool. They give you a warm coat and mittens to go in, but I'd still dress rather warm for the experience. I had on sweatpants and tennis shoes and still only lasted about 15 minutes in the Icebar. Kudos to those who can last longer.After the Icebar, we were able to check out happy hour in the bar. We ordered a bottle of the Chile Merlot, which was only 12 pounds during happy hour. We also ordered the duck fat fries for 3.5 pounds, which were good but I couldn't really taste the duck fat. Definitely something you should check out in London. It was a very unique experience and there are some good specials in the bar during happy hour.

zXhGd5ZluuLCvhBWx8NphA.text: I went here with my family and it was a unique and fun experience. It is expensive and the drinks are quite small but it is worth doing once. As you would guess, it is extremely cold! Though I tried to last our entire allotted time, I had to exit a few minutes early. My brother and parents really enjoyed as well (and they were actually able to last the full 45 mins!)

aVclu6a4nWeeeJdPMmukng.text: Cool concept, though not really a place you'd return to multiple times. More of a one time experience. Temperature was meant to be -5 degrees Celsius, but felt colder than that. Definitely true to the igloo theme and ambience, but I wish they had more of an entertainment or distraction apart from just blocks of ice. I really enjoyed my drink. It was served in an ice cube as well which was fun to drink out of. Overall, enjoyed the experience -- solid place and time.

3PZ_Z7UR2WP-8iYK-jVEjA.text: I get cold easily. And I mean easily. So turning up here in a skirt wasn't the best idea as I was shivering even before I'd got my drink! For most people though, the cosy capes seemed more than enough to keep them warm as we posed next to the ice, stroked the ice, and my boyfriend tried to melt an imprint of his hand into the ice (pretty sure it's not going to happen). Had an absolutely fantastic evening here, good - and interesting - food, cocktails that tasted like blackberry crumble, and shots like pressed apple juice. Thanks ice bar!

dT6-udDYcVXvKgLh-QMkZw.text: Icebar is such a cool place (obvious pun intended). I wanted to come here for my birthday while I was up in London seeing a show last year. We turned up and it was a Monday in June so we didn't need to book, however hadn't realised there are set time slots so we had to wait about 20 minutes to go in which wasn't too bad.I would say the only reason to come here is for the experience. I'm pleased to say I've gone but I wouldn't go again unless it was for a friends birthday or other arranged event. The fun of it is putting on the insulated poncho and the gloves and waiting to go in being told "now its very cold in there..." and you think pah, sure, they can't freeze us...They do. Everything in there is made of ice, from the bar, seats and tables to the glasses you drink from. You get one cocktail with your ticket which really isn't enough and they are fairly expensive to buy after that. But pretty damn tasty! Once you've had your cocktail, its basically time to take a gazillion photos and post them on Facebook or do the standard check-in. Of course, the gloves are so huge you get frostbite taking them...or you ask another poor soul if they wouldn't mind taking a group shot of you.My mum was blissfully unaware that the whole thing would be ice cold so she wore sandals. (it was June after all) She. Froze. I don't know how she did it but we managed to stay on there for the full 45 minutes. It was really empty when we went with only about 4 other couples, so I imagine the atmosphere is much better if it is busier near winter. All in all, definitely recommend coming here once when you're in London, but come prepared. Wear actual shoes with socks, book a slot if you're coming in peak time and maybe get some touchscreen sensitive gloves.

jbuE1xZuEiZzgS0SMf17ZA.text: Experience wise? Yes! Who doesn't want to feel like an Eskimo with a pet wolf?It's great for about 5minutes, after that your fingers start to burn and quite frankly you begin to loathe the idea of being a stupid Eskimo! What a terrible idea! What is this freezing pain!The cocktail I had was actually very nice, sweet... Drinking it out of an ice glass made the whole experience even better. They change the theme every 6months I believe, which I think is cool.Worth a visit. You get to look like little red riding hood. :)

uJF54HgIfffrOFr-7mTf_g.text: I was excited to spend my birthday here. It was our first time visiting the UK. I like the concept of the place. You can have drinks or a bite to eat with friends in a more heat inclined atmosphere before taking part of the ice experience. We ordered appetizers and a bottle of champagne before heading in to the actual ice bar. Upon entry you get an insulated hooded  cape w/ mittens to keep your hands warm. Entry includes 1 drink. It was cold but not unbearable and being intoxicated sort of balanced it out. Me and my girls had an amazing time and even met some people who were visiting from other countries who suggested they'd found the place through Yelp. All in all it was a great experience and a great way to spend my birthday.

y83VbQssstct6uLTctSIEA.text: Being new to town and missing the opportunity to do this elsewhere, I had to give it a try. I'm glad I went but I won't be back.Having purchased my ticket online I expected to walk right in but instead had to queue with everyone else then get in another line to get the printed receipt to bring in. This added unnecessary time to the process.As I was part of a larger group we waited until everyone arrived before going in however our time was limited to the ticket start time. Thus we only got 30 minutes inside.It's a very small room full of ice with one bar. Drinks are small as well. That said, the ice sculptures are cool and music is pumping loud. It is very cold even with the coat and gloves they provide so you don't want to stay too long.There is a warm bar to hang out before or after your allotted time in the ice bar. Unless you're entertaining visitors I would just as soon skip it and go somewhere else for a better drink.

i3GrS3QFMHILGudZqfuh2A.text: Loved it as much as the one I did in Stockholm. The wild life theme was pretty cool and cocktail was good! PpKTKvR18FczSh5qP_-bbQ.text: Cool experience but so much smaller than expected. The caps keep you warm enough, especially with the gloves, so that was not a concern. Weak drinks make the small room even more awkward as people just want to take pictures and leave. They must know people like pictures, and yet the lighting is still terrible. I will say that the drinks are tasty, and overall it's a cool concept, but not really worth the hype. I'd say double the size of the room and the strength of the drinks, then you have yourself a time.

DWM6MiOwHvQE6mmB5Cma7g.text: Let me start by saying that:I generally never drink alcohol.I can count the number of bars I've been in in my entire life on one hand.I agreed to go because my friend wanted to.With that said, though, Icebar is one of the most unique, fun, and high-quality establishments I've ever attended!  I booked a slot in advance on their web site, which cost around 45 British pounds (per person) for a three-course dinner and a 40-minute session in the Icebar (which includes your first cocktail).We arrived early, and were given the option of purchasing drinks in the non-ice bar, but we opted to wait for our session to start.  At our scheduled time, we had thick, heavy coats with attached gloves (and an "Ice Hotel" logo on them) put on us by the friendly staff, and we entered the Icebar.  The scenery is truly amazing.  The artistry and quality of the ice sculptures is simply beautiful.  There is also multi-colored backlighting and a working flat-screen television behind one of the panes of ice.  There is a photographer taking photos throughout, and you can view, download, or purchase them from their web site.We both opted for non-alcoholic beverages, which were very tasty!  There were also children in the Icebar, and they seemed to be having a great time!Dinner afterwards was a HUGE surprise!  For the reasonable price of the whole package, I expected the food to be average bar fare.  Instead, what we got was a fine dining experience, complete with molecular gastronomy, and wonderfully friendly and attentive staff!  We were offered a complimentary aperitif before our dinner started, were given the option to purchase anything else from the menu that wasn't already included in our purchase.  As this was my friend's first fine dining experience, we bought two additional appetizers.The food was stunning!  Everything was perfectly-cooked, perfectly-seasoned, and perfectly delicious.  I recommend Icebar's restaurant on its own, and would gladly dine there regularly if I didn't live on a different continent.

Downstairs is quiet a large space, great for the event I was attending. Staff were amazing, friendly and engaging. Tom was such a great host. Welcome cocktails were delicious! Ice bar itself was beautiful. Sadly I am not a fan of the cold so took a could of picks and checked out all the amazing, transparent ice carvings then got out. Love the Wild theme!

35TiQz8xvLKLQpDXymNM1A.text: Numerous areas of ICEBar is what makes it so great. Downstairs there's a modern and cosy restaurant along with a vibrant bar which is divided by a internal wall - which is great as you can have your meal and then grab a cocktail. Cocktails are very impressive - check out the photos. Even though one would think that London has great cocktail bars, there more rare than common. ICEBar is a great place Ice Experience is brilliant and should be checked out!! They have different themes, though when I was there, they has Wild In the City - loads of fun. Each piece of ice has been transported from the North of Sweden, thus all individual with river marks and unique features. I was the ice cave (as I like to call it) for about 20 minutes. You can get drinks in a pure ice cup, though before you start thinking about it; no, you can't take them home....just  think about it ;-) Their Bar at the entrance level is chilled place to have a drink after enjoying all the above, or even if you haven't, you can still stop in for a drink without having to do any of the above. As most bars in this areas are too full, or too expensive, ICEBar is definitely the place to go if you want a more civilised place to chat with friends within the area.100% recommend ICEBar for events, dates, groups of friends and almost every occasion.

tDnhK3SzLtpC5XKB48lxig.text: This is actually on my bucket list so when I got the chance to go to it I was absolutely thrilled!! I think the best time to go would be winter when you're already dressed up in appropriate clothing because 20 minutes into the slot I was already begging for my thermals all packed up neatly at the back of my wardrobe!! What makes this a must for those who want something quirky is it's controlled environment. Where else can you find an ice bar in London that delivers quality as well as fun from the clear ice that is delivered from abroad to the rotating theme they have throughout the year. When I visited the theme was 'wild animals' For £16.50 this is equivalent to a cinema ticket but more memorable ;-)

97oInH_n4fH9GsuVagdqrw.text: The Ice bar is a really good place to experience something new. Apparently it's really good for third dates - I wouldn't know though as I'm happily married and was long gone from the dating market. The Ice room is made of ice from sweden and it's really cold, so they give you a cape and gloves. The fun thing though is that you drink from a cup made out of ice! I thought it was quite a novel experience (being from a Tropical country) and not wanting to be in the cold for a long period of time. The reception room downstairs is also a really good function room. We threw the Yelp Unofficial Community's Launch party at the downstairs reception and Icebar had some great cocktails and canape style food which was very tasty. You can also have a DJ in there, and there's a bar area and a breakout space to do some stuff like face painting. It was fabulous. For private events, you can even have a private entrance that goes straight into your downstairs reception so it really feels like an exclusive venue. Would definitely recommend for party organisers and as a normal customer :)

_vy_wB7LrT9lipoyKPxkWg.text: A unique 45 min experience in central London. You will be provided with a thick coat and attached gloves upon arrival and then you can freely wonder in the ice room. Everything is from ice here; ice bar, ice sculptures which change from time to time and ice glass given for your drinks. Drinks are actually more size-wise of a shot thing, and drinks are more of a juice (rather than an actual alcoholic drink). It is not to substitute your usual drinking nights; more of a one time experience and that's it. Expensive but your entrance includes a free drink and you then have plenty of time for your usual instagram iced photos!

4vEPxdeViZg8jNJXlZE8lg.text: I had never been to an Icebar before, so we decided to go one night after dinner. Other than it's good location, there was nothing too special about the experience.It was expensive (forty pounds total) for about 45 minutes inside the bar. I was eager to go in and expected way more from the atmosphere and the drinks. It was a small room, crowded with a lot of other people with only a few ice sculptures. Our entrance fee to get inside included one complimentary drink in an ice cube. Although they provide gloves and a poncho, it is quite cold and after about twenty minutes we ended up leaving - also didn't want to pay 11-15 pounds for another drink. It was just a little boring and I would have rather spent my money elsewhere!

iwZeq0_3rXIvZCj2e47-3g.text: Thank you YuC and Ice Bar for a brilliant evening. A great idea with the inner animal theme.  Lovely catching up with lots of Yelpers too! Such a cool place not just because it's -5°C.  Actually, that is not as cold as you think, if you are well wrapped. I have experienced colder -15° to -23° before in Seoul and Moscow :-)We started downstairs with an assortment of  delicious canapes ranging from pork skewers to mini burgers to blue cheese balls, to parcels of chorizo and mustard, to parcels of pumpkin and goats cheese, and little glasses of prawns, jelly and cream on top. All washed down with cocktails or wine or beers.  I had a berry crumble cocktail, unusual, but I liked!  Beautiful face painting was also being done in one corner by the lovely face painter, Joanne of Jojo's face painting.  I asked for a butterfly in keeping with the inner animal theme, well, I am a "social" butterfly!  Then in groups according to our coloured wristbands, we went upstairs to the Ice Bar, the highlight of the evening.  A cape, with gloves attached, was put over our heads, which kept you quite cosy, before being let in to roam around the ice bar room.  It was fun trying to drink cocktails of vodka, bourbon or rum in square glasses made of real ice, without it slipping out of our hands! The cocktails had some great names.  I had a Horny Rhino. Very nice indeed. After 20 minutes of marvelling at the ice and beautiful ice structures and enjoying the experience, our time was up, and the capes were whisked off.Back downstairs more wine and canapes and the winner of the best photo was announced. Well done Paul S.  An inspired photo! Then the Arctic parrot, as worn by Livi S, won the best animal costume in keeping with the ice theme! We all had such fun, and that was not the end, we also all got a goody bag to take home too.  Thanks so much Carl and all the team, for making this a most enjoyable evening for everyone.  Very well organised!  Surely, this is a must place for any party, casual and fun!

The staff were incredibly friendly and I got very quickly drunk on the scrumptious cherry crumble cocktails (I need the recipe for these!)I really liked hearing about the sourcing of the pure ice and checking out the actual freezing area (though I only stayed for a quick photo op - I'm not a fan of being chilled for too long ;)I'm properly excited to come back soon and sample more of those gorgeous puff pastry/butternut squash bites too!

ZeVeL1UUMIK9paLwHb-_7g.text: The ice bar is a great concept drinking in a very cold enclosed area out of glasses made out of pure ice amongst ice sculptures. This year the ice sculpture theme is based on animals. However there was not many animals to be seen out of ice only really on TV screen.Before entering the ice bar you are given a big cape with hood and gloves to wear so don't worry about getting too cold. The cocktails are quite good maybe a slightly too sweet but still they were good. You use the same glass that is made out of pure ice throughout your experience. Even though fun I think I would of loved to of seen more ice sculptures. I properly would not go back as I feel once you have done it you have done it and as I said before the drinks were not fantastic just ok. However if you have not done it then I do recommend doing it as it a laugh and an experience.

U3RwRBDdOhppACu6EUIeAg.text: If you want to just chill (!) and drink on the rocks (!!) at the coolest (!!!) place in London, go to the Icebar! I got a Groupon for drinks here and it was SOOO worth it. First off, the bar is a little hard to find as it's in some side streets... not really a problem but I bet they'd be more popular if they were on a main road. Anyways, we arrived early for our 6:50PM reservation. We had a drink at the warm bar while we waited and the drinks were very good and strong. We got in line when our time arrived and there were about 20-25 people who also made the same reservation. They gave us these blue parka looking things and let us go in for our allotted 40 minutes. Seriously, the place is SOOOO COOLLL. The actual ice bar area is not very big and no one actually sits down and chats like a regular bar... mostly, we all just marveled at the ice designs, got a few more drinks, and took selfies. We actually left after 30 minutes because it was SOOOO cold but we didn't feel slighted or that we didn't get our money's worth. Apparently, they do different designs each September-ish and this year was Icebar Rocks (rock music). I guess they close down for a week while they change the theme so I am excited to go back later this year (or next year) for another round!!!

TSE-nMDsIn-cUQkP9NJ4lA.text: The official launch of the Yelp Unofficial Community happened last week. In the coolest venue - The Ice Bar. We had the whole of the basement for the launch where there was free food all night long, free cocktails and in the corner a face painter to turn us into animals. There was a chance to mingle with other yelp reviewers as well as local company owners. There was also the ability to go upstairs into the ice bar and experience the -5 degrees Celsius bar.  It was a lot of fun to put on the coat and gloves and walk into the freezing cold bar. Unfortunately I didn't manage to stay in there long but it was so cool to be there.We also were able to sample the cocktails on offer and they were yummy.There was a competition for best dressed and best photo. The whole atmosphere of the night was one of friendship with everyone chatting to everyone else. Lastly the night ended with a goodie bag of amazing gifts. The ice bar is such a unique venue. Well worth going along an experiencing drinking in sub-zero temperatures.

ZkerePsnr23uA3Ael-9cGg.text: I was here last week for the launch of YUC official party and a few times before for friends birthdays. Last week was fun as it was a themed launch party so people had to dress up as wild animals. I dressed up as a tiger! On arrival we were given a wristband to allocate time slots for the icebar not before being lead downstairs to where the two rooms where. There was a open bar with complimentary cocktails, wines and beers and a variety of canapes given out in the first room and in the second room there was complimentary facepainting and seating.I went to this launch event with another yelper and we enjoyed sipping on the delicious cocktails and canapes. We where stuff by the end!! The staff was welcoming and informative too. As the event continued there was a welcome speech and then each group was lead back up the stairs too the icebar where we lined up to get given our hooded jacket and gloves. Inside we where surrounded by ice sculptures and the icebar where there was a cocktail menu and complimentary cocktail given out. Each cocktail poured into an actual ice glass. The session last about 30/40mins and we then were lead out and helped to take off our hooded jackets. Good experience but time went quick for me poss due to taking alot pics and chatting!Overall, a great experience - for me, being in the actual icebar would be a one off experience but would deffo come back for the cocktails at the main bar.

XOs1ED5J1XAsH2hQzbG-XQ.text: If you get a deal to go here then it is worthwhile.I went for the champagne Ice Bar drinks followed by a three course meal.  Total cost £78, which is fab for two people in central London for a gimmick followed by a meal.The Ice Bar area allow you 45 minutes.  Although you get given the poncho and gloves, do think about what you wear on your feet.  I thought that twenty minutes was more than enough time in the Ice Bar to be honest.  It's not as big as you would think.  It's great to do for a tick box, but that's about it.  Cocktails were really tasty to be fair.We went to the restaurant and it was average.  I found the menu unnecessarily complicated, with no real "safe" options, there was literally on thing in each section that I would have eaten, so clearly I did.The beef wellington starter was a bit dry and beef over cooked.  But not by too much, yet pastry was a bit stodgy but I like it that way.The burger for the main, was distinctly average and nothing to write home about.  Quite small portions.Other half had pork belly and he said it was nice enough, they tried to over think the accompaniment though.  The parsnip nearly took my teeth out as in literally not cooked at all.Deserts were delicious and lips smacking.There were a few occasions where service was a bit meh, but on other times brilliant.  The place was rather chilly though - not being sarcastic as this is the restaurant part and not connected to the Ice Bar at all.All in all, if you have a deal, definitely go.

XSxbibOpettneRLZcfhuhA.text: I was invited to check out Icebar London for my first time ever with some fellow frequent Yelp reviewers. It was my second time at an ice bar, my first time being in Christchurch, so I can only compare it to that.I have to say my favourite feature was that the ice bar had a large 'regular' warm bar area which was nice and warm, while still being big and inviting. This was different that my first ice bar experience which was just an ice bar. As fun as it is, it's not somewhere you want to be for a long time. We got a time slot for the ice bar, which was for 45 minutes. When entering, we were given a thermal poncho, with some cut outs for our arms. The bar changes its theme often, and at the time I went, the theme was wild animals, so there were some great ice cultures around this. We also got one drink while in there, which was served in a very cool ice glass. Back in the warm bar, I had one of the best cocktails I have ever tried, which had berries and a really nice pie-like taste to it. I absolutely loved it, and really want to go back for more. The canapes we had were great as well, so don't hesitate to order food while you are there. This is a space where you can have a large group or party, perfect for different functions.Overall, I really enjoyed my visit to the Icebar London and will be returning.

9hJFWBQ7HF54Cn2pdGofkA.text: I organised a big trip to the Absolut Ice Bar for my friends and I about a year ago. We were originally going to have dinner, then go in. There was a special deal during the week for this set up, which would have been great, but unfortunately they wanted to charge me about £30/head up front. I couldn't afford to cover that for all 10 of us, so we just made reservations for the bar itself.Thought this still meant that we had to put down a deposit, it was reasonable and I was happy to cover it. We arrived at a specified time and dressed up like little eskimo spacemen, which was wholly amusing. I wondered prior to arriving whether it was an 'over the coat' job and if I'd need to bring gloves. Turns out, the thermal cape fitted nicely over my thick jacket, and I was provided with thermal mittens that are built in. I didn't get cold at all, which surprised me considering we were sitting on blocks of ice covered with furs.£15 allowed us entry for 45 minutes, and gave us a free drink (a vodka based cocktail in an ice cup). The refills were pricey at £7 a pop, but you can't really knock up too much of a bill in such a short space of time. It's a novel way to spend an evening, with plenty of photo opportunities and is most definitely worth a visit. The night remains a conversation starter to this day, but is best enjoyed in a big group I think.Worth noting that the decor changes with every season. It was 'Disco Elvis' went I went, but you'll get a different theme every 3 months.

U2-YZHdHDtdc0nf2hRSE8g.text: It's a bar made out of ice, entirely... from the actual bar furniture to your drink glasses. Everything is made out of ice. So, yes, naturally, it's freezing inside this bar. However, no worries. Upon entering this place, you pay (duh) and they let you borrow a heavy-duty poncho and gloves. So you wear that over your clothes and then enter the icy bar. It's definitely one of those touristy things you do.. wear ponchos in an ice bar, have a couple of drinks, and then skedaddle, b/c even with the poncho and a few drinks, it's still quite cold in there. It's definitely not one of those places that you hang out to chat it up... unless, you're an Eskimo.

xvyiGeZGokOFezRJsNQtjw.text: In a word, it's  COLD..... that concludes my review.......  ...but seriously, my fuzzy recollections of the Absolut Ice Bar go like this:expensive drinks in the waiting lounge, great decor, crowded inside the freezer.    I was in London and had seen this featured in one of those Discovery channel "Top 10 " lists for places to have a drink.  I went there and I guess I was expecting that one, for it to be bigger and two, to actually be allowed to be in the freezer longer than 45 minutes.    I was disappointed by the experience since you have to wait for one group of Vodka sluggin' Eskimos to slam their drinks, take the required pictures to send back home "Look ma' I'm inside an ice phone booth!" and get out inside of 45 minutes. I suppose you want that time limit or else who knows what can go wrong after you  really get hammered, inside a refrigerator.   Worst part, I tried to bring back the glass they served my Vodka in. Guess what happened to it?

6j1xtO7iv3MgCATCXr_XTw.text: Fantastic bar, very nice idea. The only downsides are that you really have to book a table in advance and the time in the actual bar is restricted. With a very warm coat, I could have had many more cocktails. For every tourist: Go there and have look, it is worth it.

LLfvTVbCgQm8qJT71ZeoHw.text: Attended a corporate event here which the host must have spent a small fortune on.  The rest of the bar was nice and the nibbley foods were fine.  The Ice Bar itself was tacky and the drinks were watered down.

cj6txqkqeApkuL6441BYww.text: did i fall to the hype of an ice bar? guilty. :)it's about 15 pounds and you get 45 mins in the bar, just like everyone else had said. Decor: Well, look up pics on the site! It's actually pretty true to the pics. We were definitely amused by all the ice and taking pictures of everything around us for the first 20-30 mins or so.Drinks: I got the Singapore Sling. MY GOODNESS, it was STRONG! I actually couldn't drink it all and gave it to my guys friends-- who were all too happy to take it, of course, haha.Bottom Line: Fall to they hype and do it once. I thought it was pretty worth my money. :)

VbSnSm3l_d1M2DGuL1EN1w.text: Ahhhhhh tourism at its best.   I've also been to the motherland one in Stockholm, and have to say, the London one oddly puts it to shame.  They do change the interior every so often so that if you haven't been in a while, it'll be a different ice bar next time you return, once they had an ice-phone booth, one time they made ice DJ decks, the last time I went it was sort of mechanical-looking.  Like others say, the price includes one drink, though there's special time slots you can book for a premium price that will allow you to indulge in unlimited refills.   For a tourist-trappy bar, I actually usually have fun here, though I take away a star due to the wretched stench the gloves from the parkas leave on your hands, they need to wash those things!

rSo1EFk6cpmU2AGeUnIbkQ.text: Although I'd like to say this is probably a huge tourist attraction, I went with a group of Londoners who had just as much fun as I did!  Yes, there's a cover, and you only get to stay in 40-45 min, but screw it, you're hanging out with friends in an igloo!The cover included a drink, mine was very tasty!  There are random ice sculptures all over the place that are pretty cool.  Some of my friends had a contest to see who could keep their bare hand (they give you gloves) on the ice the longest, yea I have mature friends.Overall, it was a great time and a great place to start out the night!

emlrbYgZuEUssq8wyfNWig.text: The Ice Bar was good fun, we arrived to a bit of a wait as they where packing a fair few people inside the very small bar, but once we had been given our capes and gloves off we went in search of vodka. At first I thought the cape was unecessary but after 15 minutes I was freezing. You got to pick a vodka drink from the menu and it was served in an ice glass, re fills where free if your glass lasted long enough. The theme was aquatic, there where engravings in the ice of underwater scenes. Overall it was a good laugh for a one off experience, more of a tourist rather than a drinking out experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom

L_A1WDvSNes7J_CgVn-FnQ.text: The concept and the idea is quite cool- My friends and I came here on our first visit to London, I think overall it's worth visiting at least once, but I highly doubt I'll be coming back, at least not in the actual ice room.Cool concept and good drinks, but the service was a little lacking, and people seemed a little snobby. Overall a good experience.

g7t_Fdu4lbSzc_K_1Wzteg.text: The Icebar... Novelty ice themed bar. It does what it says it does on the tin. In summary, you pay £15 per person for entry for 45 minutes and a drink. The drinks are served in an ice-glass and are about a 50ml serving, so rather small. You get a coat, with fur gloves attached. The room itself is just a square, with some benches (ice) and the bar itself. It's quite pretty and well designed with UV-Lighting making certain drinks "radioactive" looking. Overall though, it's hardly a great place. Rebuys are very expensive, staff are obviously cold and not that happy with serving. Having said that, there is an outside heated area and a 'warm' bar as well. It's in a good location with plenty of eating and other drinking places around. I think I'd rather spend £15 on cocktails at Dirty Martini :)

mE288OwUTMjmFYwhP1qPkQ.text: A great novelty bar, particularly to kick off a night. I met up with a few friends for a 45 mins slot here. It's not cheap at £15, and the ice room is pretty tiny, but it's good fun. The cocktails were tasty, although I was slightly worried about my lips sticking to the ice! There's a tiny bar area, fur (fake?) covered seating, and pretty much everything in the room is ice themed. You'll freeze your bits off, but the alcohol helps a little :) Might be worth booking ahead though if you're considering, as it does get very busy!

4IR06RuZ-m8CFK1xNXNN2Q.text: It's a bar made of ice. Everything. Just try it, once. 5 stars for the idea and execution. I was surprised that things weren't melting. They keep it sufficiently cold.

Tqfge1ZUyq0m4Tud83FFxA.text: Ice, ice, baby This is quite a large bar with a side room all covered in ice. £15 for 45 minutes and a drink seems quite expensive at first, but 45 minutes is about all I could handle in there before my glove covered hands started to get a bit chilly and the icey floor made its way through my boots and pervaded my feet. (poncho with furry hood and gloves is provided!) Really good novelty place completely made of ice with UV lighting for added effect! The seats are made of ice, as is the tables and there are large cogs cut into the walls (for some reason). We got a drink included in the price and I went for a strawberry creamy type thing. After I'd polished that off I went up to the bar to get another one. This time I wanted the radioactive drink but the lady wouldn't wash out my glass for me, (I say 'glass' - really i mean 'ice' as the drinking recepticeles are also made of ice) telling me I could buy another one at a price of £4. Having watched some of my recepticle melt already I felt £4 to rent the solid state of water seemed a bit steep and as the bar lady stirred my drink with some sort of radioactive stick, I felt that the strawberry remenants of my previous drink were probably the least of my worries! Needless to say, I lived to tell the tale.

Ji-_GWMVQ5lRylG9z4t36w.text: I always drop by the Icebar every time I'm in London and it's not going to be any different in a week's time.  I love the ice glass, the silvery blue thermal cape, and the very flavorful Life's Apeach.

pQpEU4mYcBnlE4HLt9ph-Q.text: For the £12 entrance fee, you get a drink included and the experience of hanging around in a bar made out of ice....that is basically it.The drink i had was good, but the ice glass only allowed for a very small drink portion and if you thik about it £12 comes out to about  $21 which is absolutely ridiculous to pay for a drink made with absolut vodka.Of course the reason people come to this bar is for the experience not the drinks. It was fun, you get to dress up in an iceman/spaceage suit and walk around like youre in the arctic tundra for 45 mins while youre drinking your ice cold beverage.I'd say it was worth doing once, but definietly not worth going back to again. I can buy an entire bottle of absolut vodka for the price i paid to get into this bar.

xt4Ppu5gOcC1i10Ahhb1FA.text: It is expensive to go here and there is a time limit. Then again it makes sense to have a time limit because it's flipping cold as hell in there. If in fact, hell is cold and not hot. Knowing that dress accordingly, flip flops might not be the way to go. Maybe dressing cute isn't the way to go either because they give you an extraordinarily big warm cape that also smells really bad. It covers anything cute you are wearing. The great thing about this place is they do have unique, strong drinks. They also taste really good. You'll never know there was any alcohol in it until you start feeling it a bit later. It's a concept bar so that kind of gives it a cool factor as well. I mean really, are you planning on transforming your bedroom into an ice room. Probably not. So give it a try. If you actually live in London you might want to avoid it as it is very touristy. Which is why I was there.

5jsRTQOaI2GRLzwzwPW1bw.text: I cant yet claim to have visited The Absolut IceBar - though most who go claim it is lot more fun and a lot less tacky than you expect. I have however had good experiences at the Wolf Bar in belowzero - which is all part of the same overall establishment. Good sophisticated ambience, excellent cocktails and much nicer to sit in for long periods of time than I imagine the ICEBAR is. Sit, enjoy and relax and watch the tourist rushing past

LJiBIOTtzJKFV76WFFjl1Q.text: I was sooo excited to go to an ice bar. But when we got there and it was 15 pounds each to get in (just to get in - included one small drink) it killed a bit of the excitement. Coming from the US - 15 pounds at that time was equal to $30! And on top of that we had to wait an hour and a half to get a time slot to enter. But when we finally got in I was pretty excited to get to wear my thick blue slip on parka with attached hood... the pictures alone were worth the 15 pounds. And the drinks came in a glass completely made of ice. Most of the interior of the bar was ice - the walls, seats, and decorations. Pretty much the only thing not ice was the actual bar which was metal. All in all it was a cool experience (literally...) but not one I am likely to repeat anytime soon.

5DyPrTLVI474INAnR_WhUg.text: A quirky experience. A good idea if you've got friends visiting London who have done all the usual London things. £12 (or £15 on Fri and Sat nights) gets you into the bar for 40 mins, a 'designer' thermal cape with gloves and a Absolut vodka cocktail served in a glass made of ice. It is quite small, and perhaps not as impressive as you would hope, but it's still a 'cool' place to go. Cocktail refills are £6 each, don't lose your glass or you have to pay for a new one. A good range of vodka cocktails, and the ice glass becomes like a lolly pop, I nearly ate the whole glass. What was nice, was coming out of the Ice Bar and feeling like it was really warm outside!

mTwhfR3iZT3PaQ3y0OY-Cg.text: This was an interesting experience at least.  The build-up is fun and then when you get in there it's cool to take photos and stuff.  But then ... it gets old real fast.  You stand there, drink your drink, and then you get cold and start thinking ... what am I doing here?  Bottom line, good to experience once while visiting London, but not something you'll want to do again.

Oq509sceBk9LMbkZFq_p-g.text: Must do if you are visiting London. Check out their website first.  We found a great deal (i forget the exact price). It gave us 45 minutes, open bar at 7pm on a Thursday. We figured getting at least 4 drinks would make our money's worth. We had time to drink more than 4..The drinks are not huge, but are strong! My friends and I came out pretty buzzed/drunk.Take lots of pictures (they had a photographer in there too who took some for their site).Talk to the bartenders, they will tell you some cool information about the bar. We were lucky to not have a big crowd in there, so there were no lines to the bar. They limit the amount of people that go in at one time, so that was a plus.

AL-dP6451_MF6Om1WmP3LA.text: Definitely worth a visit! Total novelty, very fun, you're very looked after and entertained and the vodka is great too  then you have the fun of eating the glass once you've had the drink! ;-)Great opportunity for silly photos in silver suits!

eWIsJqa0IEdZ7yh1w81BrQ.text: Ice bar off the Hook, you have to go there to believe it!!!!!!Glasses made out of ice, has got to be the icing on the cake!!!!!

WGZEHJr_xApABxVM2EZ8Tw.text: Located off the infamous Ice Bar, there's nothing particularly memorable about this lounge.  The lighting was right, the level of noise was good for conversation, and the cocktail list was long and impressive - but there still wasn't anything that set it apart from any other loungey venue.I came with a couple of friends because we wanted somewhere not-too-loud to chat while imbibed a couple of cocktails.  My friends had a fruity lychee martini, and I went with a stronger and less sweet concoction in the form of the "Sagini" - gin, pomegranate, and sage - I was pleasantly surprised at how well that all worked together.The service was pretty nonexistent - and at times verged on curt.  Our waitress rushed us to order and then brought us our bill before we'd said that we were finished.  I'd say that the aloof service we experienced was definitely the worst part of the place.I'd come back here only if I were in an absolute pinch for a lounge bar.  This would be a good setting for a business drink perhaps, but it's far too formal and lacking any real cool allure to come back with friends - not even for a drink post Ice Bar.

Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Entry to the Ice Bar
Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. The Sagini

QWrOICufvE6Uu-_50kqq1Q.text: Once you have gone in an had one shot its like .. what now

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom

WXVIB0VK7AhF3Cpu1tYJGA.text: Cold Cold Cold... I usually try to avoid any place where I know for certain that it will be filled with tourists, but I finally gave in and thought what the hell. The moment I walked in I realized that a little bit of hell wouldn't be too bad it was so freakin cold. But I could see why people are drawn to this place, it's really cool and it's something I will never forget, you can say that the memories are frozen in my mind. The drinks are steep but then again it is from a glass that can only be used once before it melts.An eskimo for a day with friends was worth the cold, next stop the Ice Hotel in Jukkasjärbi, Sweden.

DWS2q8_mDa07gSKqLXyt2w.text: I found this bar through Yelp. I thought I would check it out. It was amazing. Everyone should checkout the icebar when they are in London. It is pretty expensive and your only allowed 40 minutes in the bar. Overall, it was a good experience  I only lasted 20 minutes in the bar, it was too cold

Ck7xZni2TJdnTCTbeorolw.text: My fiance took me here for something different.  We took the "let's get our money's worth" approach, and spent most of our 45 minutes trying all of the drinks on the menu.  I assumed it might be hard to get a drink (and at times it was); however, we had no trouble getting in about 8 shots/drinks each!The bartender's attitudes were a little bit "I hate my job"ish; however, it didn't ruin our time.One thing that DID bother us, was that they started the 45 minute countdown as soon as the first person in line put on their poncho.  I felt like we only had 35 minutes by the time we got in there.It was definitely a good time.  We went to the restaurant after, and that was YUMMY!  (although, being tipsy didn't hurt)

vZtI-kRFQOB9GvnV6pBVKw.text: The Ice Bar was a lot of fun, selection of 20 drinks from the menu and the staff very pleasant & friendly. 4-Star but read below After our chilled fun in the Ice Bar we were ready for Belowzero. Started off with the waiters taking too long with our drinks, in fact we made a dent with the bottle of water before our cocktails and wine arrived. The Cocktail: Ordered two Hibiscus Royale and we got two glasses of Champagne with raspberry juice, which isn't a cocktail on the menu. Later, I quizzed the barman over this cocktail and the replay was the Hibiscus is too expensive for them to use. THEN WHY SAY 'Hibiscuc Royale' on the menu? Change it!! The Wine: Ordered a bottle of Pinot Grigio, which arrived warm... they did have it in an ice bucket 1/3 filled with water and a few ice cubes in it. I had to ask for more ice in the ice bucket and the wine as chilled right when we finished our main course. Suggestion for those of you going to the Ice Bar first, order and take your white wine with you to chill for  hour. The Food: Arrived cold, not warm but cold  cold duck isn't my favorite dish but the side vegs were warm. Overall, it's a tourist trap style restaurant, not good service, poor quality of food for that price and very poor quality on drinks service

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom

pD-9Io6iD6fa174Bq6QXPw.text: This place is pretty neat and you should at least experience it once while you're in London.  The entire bar is made out of ice - literally from the tables to the shot glasses.  It was about 15-16 pounds I believe and with that admission everyone gets one free shot and 45 minutes inside.  I think there's also the option of paying 23 pounds and it would be open bar but you would still only get 45 minutes inside.Before entering everyone gets these cool blue cloaks and gloves and all.  I would definitely advice wearing closed toe shoes. (haha, it gets quite cold especially if you were wearing sandals like me)One thing I learned going here is to NOT SMASH THE ICED GLASSES they give you. It'll get you kicked out so fast! We apologized for not knowing any better and you can guess how unhappy even the people at the cloak stand were with us.  hahaThis was definitely a memorable experience!

xAN7K4HrKGDkXUUqs3AypA.text: Everyone knows what an excellent idea the invention of ice cream is. It's the perfect meeting of happiness, joy and cold. The same can be said, to a lesser degree, of the Absolut Ice Bar near Oxford Circus. It's a great, if frozen idea, and worth the £15 entry fee. This will get you the coldest 40 minutes you've ever experienced and a free Absolut drink in a glass made completely of ice. The place is kept at a temperature of minus eight degrees Celsius and my first mission was to try get my tongue stuck to one of the icy carvings. Then I thought about how many other people as to how many other people had possibly tried this and sent my tongue from whence it came, quickly. The Ice Bar itself is quite small, and is complemented by a stylish normal bar for when the cold gets a little too much. You are given a combination of gloves and a big snowman jacket when you go in. I would love to see who is brave to decline this: even though I was dressed for the full onslaught of the British winter I still felt frozen even wearing the huge Ice Bar jacket. I sipped on my Absolut drink, hoping it would fill me with warmth. Sadly it did not. This bar is a must-see attraction, though once you've been you're likely not to return too often.

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Ice Bar

lbE-S5BgH9YhGtXR9Bn65A.text: Ice Bar, as its name suggests, is quite a frosty little place.  Everything inside is made of ice imported from Sweden and means that the temperature has to be maintained at a very low level to stop the place from melting.  As a result, upon entrance you are presented with thick coats and gloves to keep out the biting cold.It costs £15 just to get into this place, though you do get a complimentary vodka drink as well, and should you want more the prices remain quite high.  The drinks themselves are provided by Absolut vodka whcih means they're pretty damn tasty.I went here with a large group of friends for a bit of a laugh and that's pretty much all you should expect.  It's quite a novelty to drink from ice glasses wearing a heavy coat but the high prices mean it's not somewhere you likely to come back to again and again.

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom

9JQE5T4hn1Ixn7DozNfifQ.text: Is not really worth time,there is nothing special,i just went there to see what the big fuzz was about....well u could do that at your house,get naked and squeeze ur self in ur fridge..easier more fun and cheaper

wn1rmrvCTLdTdwxRg5XATA.text: Very "cool" place.  You get a poncho and gloves and go into a room completely made of ice for 45 minutes.  I only lasted 30 minutes!  Even your drink comes in a nice glass.  Very neat concept and definitely a fun thing to do if you're in London or any other location that offers it.  Good photo ops too!

NCD27X9oeJQpd0l_9XmL2A.text: The Absolut Ice Bar is exactly as the name suggests totally made from ice- from the walls, tables,chairs and actual glasses that they serve drinks in. The ice bar is kept permanently at minus 5 degrees, and every 6 months the design is changed to give it a new look. It is so popular in London that you have to book online to sample this new bar.It is the brainchild of a Swedish entrepreneur who has made everything from the waters of River Torne- a very famous Swedish river. Entrance costs 12.00 pound per person and with that you alsoget a thermal cape and a hood to keep you warm in case it gets too cold. You are allowed to sit in the bar for upto 40 minutes at a time in case you freeze to death.

photos.caption: Photo of Belowzero Ice Bar - London, United Kingdom. Ice and snow

N66umCUjR0hMEzLb20j5Xw.text: If the taxi driver doesn't know what you're talking about, tell them you want to go to the Absolut bar. At least that's what our taxi driver knew it by. I studied abroad and one weekend we all decided to go to the Icebar. A lot of people skipped out because of the expensive cover charge, but I thought the experience was well worth the money. For 16 pounds, you get 40 minutes inside the bar fully made of ice "from North Sweden" and a drink. The drinks were small, but this isn't the place to get wasted at. Going here is one of my most fond memories of London--it was so fun! I never expected it to be so fun. Be sure to wear socks and shoes because your feet get super cold! You won't want to stay the full 40 minutes either, but the time you do spend there will be really fun. Well, if you've never been to an icebar that is. I wouldn't mind coming back or trying out another icebar back at home after going to this one.Even waiting in line and watching other people get "hooded" was exciting. The parkas and gloves they give you are not dirty and keep you warm the whole time. Well, except your feet. My friend who wore sandals wasn't having that much fun.  Anyway, I recommend that it's a touristy thing that everyone should try :)

rjWs1FcoFaC5z6eBqfn60A.text: What are the qualities that i like in a bar in central london ?1. Open post midnight on Friday. Check.2. Its not too crowded. Check. Although the ice bar still has a big queue, seven of us could get into below zero and got a table to sit.3. Its not too loud. Check. The music was nice and soft and we could hear each other, which is too much to expect in most pubs in the area at that time.4. Nice cocktails. Check. Not too expensive also. I had a white chocolate (with vodka and some white version of Baileys) and a bellini. They make it well and are not stingy with the alcohol.5. Good service. Well, we were too drunk to notice anything about the service.On the whole, a very good place to come to post your friday night parties.

QOq9BDzY1nCdn7YG8Qgspg.text: It was a good experience, something new but we couldn't stay in there for the whole 40 min slot we only stayed for 20 min. The place is very interesting but too small. Everyone should go.

d6PsEZBPjOocDkYc8Hjo8A.text: This was super-major touristy but OK, just know that you are in for major kitch but it was much smaller than I thought and the drinks weren't that great. If you're in for a touristy experience go here but I guess I'm glad we can say we did it.
